name: 1625 Independent People
description:
1625 Independent People works with young people aged 16 to 25 who are

homeless, leaving care or at risk of homelessness in Bristol, South 

Gloucestershire, North Somerset and Bath and North East Somerset.   


We support those who are already homeless and those at risk of homelessness, including young people who are rough sleeping, and those who are hidden homeless. 1625ip provides support to help young people find and/or sustain their accommodation as well as providing safe and stable supported housing that is affordable and accessible.

Most young people we support have experienced childhood trauma. We offer specialist services to support young people to manage and overcome their trauma, and build confidence so they can thrive as an independent adult.

We also provide a range of specialist support to help young people secure and sustain suitable education, employment and training.

organization.name: 1625 Independent People
organization.description:
1625 Independent People works with young people who are homeless, leaving care or at risk of homelessness in Bristol and the South West.

Our services ranges from signposting or advice, to intensive one-to one support, supported housing, group activities and peer support.

name: 2 Way St Bristol
description:
2Way St is a self funding support group for users/carers that have experience emotional distress or mental health, its a space to explore issues affecting us.

They have a therapy room open for anyone interested, with competitive rates of hire cost offering a local beautiful room with portable massage table, the room is ready for counselling sessions, 1-1 sessions or small meetings as well as massage, reiki and all other healing skills.

Please get in touch for further information or to request a booking form either via Facebook or 07597922718

Prices:

£10 a hour for one session

£7 a hour per session if you are looking to book more than one session.

Twitter page: https://twitter.com/2waystAt2wayst

organization.name: 2 Way St Bristol
organization.description: 2Way St is a self funding support group for users/carers that have experience emotional distress or mental health, its a space to explore issues affecting us.

name: 50+ Gardening Group
description:
Welcoming weekly drop in gardening session for people aged 50+ Weekly 3 hour held at community site Frome Valley Growing Project. Please do get in contact if you have any accessibility issues and we can describe our site layout and accommodate needs where we can. Activities include; mindfulness practices, Celtic wheel of the year celebrations, growing food to promote biodiversity, no-dig gardening methods to improve soil health, saving and using local seed and identifying native plants, trees and animals. We hope people who come along will experience improved health and well being and develop new local connections to land and to people. 

Running from 6th March 2025 - 30th October 2025

organization.name: South Glos Nature Health and Wellbeing Network

name: @symes Community Building
description:
Whether you are holding a large or small meeting, a training event, a counselling session, or one-to-one advice sessions, we can accommodate you.

This is a thriving and well supported business and community hub. Our business and reception team provide the reception services, facilities service and business advice and support.

The @symes eco-building has been designed to be accessible, welcoming and environmentally friendly. Features include solar panels, under-floor heating, rainwater harvesting, energy saving lighting and automatic switches.

Our vision is for the @symes building to be a community and business hub which provides opportunities for services, community activities and events which enhance the wellbeing of the people in the surrounding communities.

Facilities

  • FREE Wi-Fi
  • Lift
  • Large upstairs meeting room
  • Accessible toilets, including disabled toilets on ground and first floor, plus shower on first floor
  • Baby change on ground floor
  • Direct level access to disabled parking bays, cycle rack and free parking
  • Equipment hire – high definition projector, DVD player, TV, flipchart, laptop
  • Photocopying/faxing available on reception – there is a small charge
  • All meeting rooms can be hired hourly, half day (4 hours) or all day
  • Public access to computers
  • Phone for 0800 numbers in the reception

Opening hours to the public

Monday – 9am – 5pm
Tuesday – 9am – 5pm
Wednesday – 9am – 5pm
Thursday – 9am – 5pm
Friday – 9am – 5pm
Saturday – 11am – 5pm (Library only)
Sunday – Closed

organization.name: Hartcliffe and Withywood Community Partnership
organization.description: HWCP is an independent, community led organisation. We are here to make Hartcliffe, Withywood, (and surrounding areas) places that work for everybody. HWCP help make sure the community can make decisions about local issues, and HWCP initiate activities or projects and promote local partnership work. We believe in empowering local residents and building communities.

You can use the website to print Easy Read examples that are being used by other clinicians to help you and your patients. 

If you do develop new health information, you can share it by going to the ‘Contact Us’ page and submitting your document.

name: Abbotswood Action Group
description:
Abbotswood Action Group Abbotswood Action Group was created 14 years ago and is the local community group which encourages and hosts regular gatherings of anyone and everyone who lives, works, is employed within, or has a care about this area. We discuss ideas and make plans which help bring the local community together, tackle issues, voice concerns to local authorities, and also improve the local environment.

Contact Alex Swatton (Community Coordinator) at AlexandraSwatton@southernbrooks.org.uk, or on 07890 569196. Alex works in partnership with Abbotswood Action Group.

Visit their website here: www.abbotswoodaction.org

organization.name: Southern Brooks Community Partnership
organization.description:
We’re a community development organisation, bringing people together to build strong communities. Since 1988, we’ve been working with people of all ages to help them live happy, healthy lives.
What do we do?

We work with communities to understand local needs, and bring people together to find better ways of doing things.
We provide practical support to help people get on in their lives, from training courses to job clubs to one-to-one support.
We run a community café and youth centre, where people can connect, try new things and get support to make changes in their lives and communities.
We work with families, older people and children and young people

name: ACAS - South West Region
description:
Acas South West works with employers of all sizes, employees and trade unions in Bristol, Devon, Wiltshire, Dorset, Gloucestershire, Somerset and Cornwall to improve organisational performance by providing practical, expert advice and training.

Acas believe that introducing simple steps such as ensuring line managers have the essential skills they need to lead their people increases productivity and helps businesses to grow. This is exactly the sort of thing that Acas South West can help you with through our free advice and training events.

Acas is an independent public body that receives funding from the government.

We provide free and impartial advice to employers, employees and their representatives on:

  • employment rights
  • best practice and policies
  • resolving workplace conflict

When things go wrong, we help to resolve workplace disputes between employers and employees.

Telephone Helpline: 0300 123 1100

name: Access Able
description: Access Able Access Able has been supplying the community with mobility and homecare aids since 2003. We sell, hire, repair & service a range of products from mobility scooters, stairlifts & wheelchairs to daily living aids. We also supply a vast range of products and pride ourselves in having a team of friendly, knowledgeable staff as well as providing essential information whenever you need it.

organization.name: Access Able
organization.description:
We've been supplying our community with mobility and homecare aids since 2003. We sell, hire, repair & service a range of products from mobility scooters, stairlifts & wheelchairs to daily living aids.
Our friendly knowledgeable staff are on hand to give essential information when you need it.

name: Access Sport
description:
Access Sport is a charity meeting the urgent need to improve children and young people’s health and wellbeing, working solely with young people in deprived communities and with a strong emphasis on young disabled people. 

We develop community sports clubs, equipping local people to provide transformational development opportunities for children and young people, irrespective of their background or ability.

We build, equip and up-skill local sports clubs and turn them into thriving local facilities, connected into other local partners such as schools, disabled people’s organisations and other local charities – all working together to deliver real change and opportunity for local young people.

We train and support volunteer sports coaches and club leaders in a range of vital skills such as establishing new sessions to attract more deprived and disabled young people, building personal development pathways for participants towards education or employment and building the financial sustainability of the club so it can grow and serve more local young people for years to come. 

We are the only charity in the UK today focussed entirely on doing this and we have developed a unique model that is measurable, cost-effective and replicable. This club development model has been recognised with a number of awards, including most recently Best Sports Charity, Community or CSR initiative at the 2017 Sports Business Awards.

organization.name: Accessport
organization.description:
Access Sport is a charity meeting the urgent need to improve children and young people’s health and wellbeing, working solely with young people in deprived communities and with a strong emphasis on young disabled people. 

We are working to combat shocking levels of exclusion, hardship and poor health faced by millions in the UK today. For example:
 

Health – the UK has the highest level of childhood obesity in Europe with one in five children obese by the time they leave primary school[i]. Just 15% of girls aged 11-15 and 22% of boys achieve the government recommended guidelines of an hour of moderate exercise each day[ii].

Exclusion – disabled people are four times more likely to be out of work than non-disabled people[iii] and only 18% of disabled people regularly engage in sport despite 70% wanting to[iv]. A 2017 UN inquiry concluded that the UK was not ensuring the UN Convention on Disabled People’s Rights.

Hardship – more than half of all children in the UK’s poorest areas are now growing up in poverty[v] and poverty is also experienced by nearly half of all families in which there is a disabled person[vi]

Sport is an incredibly powerful way to combat these issues and to transform the lives not only of deprived young people but also their families and surrounding communities. And yet, despite this, our most deprived communities are very often those most lacking in accessible sporting facilities.

name: Accessible Transport 4 U
description:
Door to door accessible service for people who prefer to have their own supportive and safe transport. 

We pride ourselves on helping you to get out and enjoy life, to become more active or just to do what you need or want to do day to day. 
Our aim is to make every journey you take a stress free door to destination experience.  Whether it’s a few miles to the local supermarket or across the country to visit family. The service runs 365 days a year 24:7, including Christmas and bank holidays. We operate from the South West of England to anywhere in the UK mainland.

Once you become a member you can book the service for regular journeys in advance and do not need to telephone again unless you need to cancel the booking. Our booking process is simple – just ring, email or text us the details and we will get back to you to confirm your booking as soon as possible.  We do ask you give at least a week’s notice of any booking, however, in an emergency, bookings may well be possible. NEVER put off ringing us.
“I use this company all the time. They get me to work and back every day. They take me to all my doctors and hospital appointments. I would be lost without this company. The drivers are very helpful. It is community transport not a taxi so sometimes you may have to compromise. However, it provides a great service and allows those of us with mobility issues to get out and about”.  (Member September 2021)

Typical journeys our current members make include; hospital, dentist, or doctors’ appointments, shopping, work, respite/holiday breaks, sport activities and social events.
“We use this company for my son’s hospital, school, absolutely everywhere we would be very lost without this company amazing drivers”.  (Member’s mother October 2021)

For more information please contact us whichever way is suited to you. Our landline number is 0117 9657449 or if you prefer texting please text 07773194950 (this is our emergency 24:7 contact telephone).  If no-one is available to answer your telephone call always leave a message, we always return calls as soon as we can.  Alternatively you can email; at4u@accessibletransport4u.org.uk

Our service is intended to be independent and flexible to meet the needs of our members. We are a not for profit community interest company whose aims are to provide a financially, as well as physically, accessible service to our members to get out and about, doing things they otherwise would not do because of transport issues.

We receive grants from charitable organisations which enables us to subsidise some journeys, but not all. So it is best to obtain quotes for longer journeys.  We do not receive funding from any local council in order to keep our transport services flexible, but do operate under contracts from Bristol, South Gloucestershire and North Somerset to provide specific transport services.
We are keen to expand into other areas in the South West and further afield under our franchise business plan.

name: Action for M.E
description:
We are here for anyone living with or supporting someone with M.E./CFS of any age, anywhere in the UK. You are not alone.

Along with our free information, support and advocacy services (see below), we are able to offer Healthcare Services following our merger with the ME Trust in January 2022. 

Our clinical team includes a doctor, physiotherapists, counsellors and chaplains, offering individually tailored whole-person care. As a charity, we charge fees for our Healthcare Services only to cover our costs, and a bursary for up to 50% of fees may be available, depending on your circumstances.

  • Call 0117 927 9551 (10am to 4.30pm Monday to Friday) or
  • email us to speak with a member of the team.

For more in-depth support, we can refer you to other Action for M.E. services:

  • Advocacy for adults
  • Advocacy for children and young people with M.E., and Family Support for their parents and loved ones
  • Peer-support forums for all ages
  • Healthcare Services including a doctor, physiotherapists, counsellors and chaplains.

organization.name: Action for M.E
organization.description:
Information, support and advocacy:-

We are here for anyone living with or supporting someone with M.E./CFS of any age, anywhere in the UK. You are not alone.

We are keeping our website up to date with the latest on Coronavirus and M.E., and sharing these updates on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. Please get in touch or follow us on social media to share your thoughts, ideas and concerns with us, and we will do all we can to support you and others with M.E.
Call 0117 927 9551 to speak to someone from our Information, Advocacy and Support Service, make a donation, find out about fundraising or membership or speak to the editor of our InterAction membership magazine.

name: Active Together for Dementia
description:
Active Together supports people living with early stage dementia to remain active.  Each volunteer is matched with a person living with dementia with whom they share an interest. Each matched pair goes out regularly and participate in a shared interest or activity – current outings include cycling, meditation classes, visiting galleries and simply going for a walk and a cup of tea.

Volunteers receive training and ongoing support and expenses are covered. We are currently recruiting volunteers for this rewarding role – if you are interested in volunteering please go to the Volunteer with us page and download a role description and an application form. 

If you know someone living with dementia who would like an Active Together volunteer to go out with please contact Clare Havard on 0117 440 4303 or email clarehavard@ageukbristol.org.uk.

organization.name: Age UK Bristol
organization.description: Age UK Bristol works to improve the lives of older people in Bristol through a range of different services.Age UK Bristol is an independent local charity, federated to Age UK (as a local partner) working together with and for older people locally, regionally and nationally.

name: Activities at KWHLC
description:
Helping you to achieve better health and wellbeing, no matter where you are starting from. It’s easier to make changes with someone cheering you on!

We offer a range of services and activities for all ages, and all levels of health and fitness – basically there is something for everyone! 

The groups currently taking place at the Healthy Living Centre are:

Monday Walking Group. Take a stroll around the Health Park grounds in the fresh air. Meet 10.15am ready for 10.30am start.

Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday walking groups. These walks take place in local green spaces.

Art Ease Group. Tuesday or Wednesday Morning, 9.45am-12.00pm.

Fun and Fab Women’s Support Group. Thursdays 10.00am-12.00pm

Man Alive Men’s group, Monthly breakfast on the 1st Friday of the Month, and various activities or meetings throughout the month.

Move Together Strength and Balance. Wednesdays, 11.00am-12.15pm. A fun exercise session to strengthen the body and mind.

Stretch and Roll Women’s Exercise Class – Thursdays, 7.30pm-8.30pm. Women’s Exercise class with an introduction Jiu Jitsu and Yoga.

organization.name: Knowle West Healthy Living Centre
organization.description:
Helping you to achieve better health and wellbeing, no matter where you are starting from. It’s easier to make changes with someone cheering you on!

We offer a range of services and activities for all ages, and all levels of health and fitness – basically there is something for everyone! The outdoor areas include play facilities, picnic areas, art installations, an Amphitheatre, outdoor gym equipment, a measured mile for walking or running, and football and basketball nets.

Our main goal is to provide high quality services to prevent illness, promote good health and assist recovery after medical treatment. We are happy to answer any questions you may have and look forward to meeting you soon.

name: Activities at Zion
description:
Zion Bristol is well loved Community Cafe in BS13 that runs a large variety of community events, children’s groups, support groups, ticketed events and provides spaces to hire for meetings, groups and private events. Zion is open Monday- Friday 9am-5pm, with the kitchen open and serving delicious food 9am-1.30pm.


Check out the regular events on our page Home - Zion Bristol

organization.name: Zion Bristol
organization.description:
In 2010, work began to restore the building as a centre for the community and to provide Bedminster Down with a safe creative space for all the community to use.
Zion provides a daytime café alongside facilities for families with a soft play area for kids. We run over 200 activites and events each year. This inspiring venue is available to rent for meetings, parties, workshops and much, much more.

name: Activity Group - Redfield (St Anne's)
description:
Currently running virtually, activity groups give people affected by dementia the opportunity to take part in structured activities. Run by a facilitator and supported by volunteers, who encourages and supports people to take part, the groups are also a chance to relax and socialise. 

Due to the outbreak of Coronavirus we developed a new way of delivering our groups for people living with dementia, using a telephone, smartphone, tablet or computer.

Our Group Coordinators will give full information about joining and discuss options for access requirements.

We are currently in the process of planning our return to face-to-face groups. Please do get in touch if you’d like to join virtually, or need any further support.

organization.description: Alzheimer’s Society is the UK’s leading dementia charity. We campaign for change, fund research to find a cure and support people living with dementia today.

name: Adult Cycling Activities
description:
Life Cycle UK's mission is to help more people get cycling, to transform lives and the environment.  

In our age of climate emergency, rising inequality and public health crisis, we believe: 

·        More cycling is vital for better physical, mental and environmental health 

·        Cycling can be safe, affordable and practical for most short journeys 

·        With the right support, almost anyone can cycle 

In order to achieve this, we have a range of supportive services to help get people on their bikes and exploring Bristol. 


Get Cycling! Courses 
Our 6- week group cycling courses are aimed at both beginners and returners, so whatever your skills and confidence levels our instructors can work with you to reach your cycling goals. The 2-hour sessions are fun, sociable and relaxed, and take place once a week. 

One-to-One Cycle Lessons 
If you would prefer to learn 1-1, our cycle instructors can meet you near your home and complete up to three one hour lessons with you for free. 

Cycle Buddies 
Our Cycle Buddies volunteer scheme is for those wanting an extra supportive hand as they continue their cycling journey. You will be matched with a volunteer in your area who can help you explore local roads, route plan and build further towards your cycling goal. 

Group Rides 
Join our Group Rides to explore safe, cycle-friendly routes around Bristol in friendly and supportive company. Choose from either our Supported Leisure Rides, Over 55’s Group Rides or Two's Company tandem rides for people who are visually impaired or disabled.


Find out about all our services here: Our services | Life Cycle UK

organization.name: Life Cycle UK
organization.description:
Life Cycle UK is a registered charity (1077575) that was founded in 1999 and now works with 9,000+ people a year.

In our age of climate emergency, rising inequality and public health crisis, we believe:

More cycling is vital for better physical, mental and environmental health.
Cycling can be safe, affordable and practical for most short journeys.
With the right support, almost anyone can cycle.
Find out what services we offer here.

Our Vision
A world with clean air and healthy people where cycling is the chosen mode of transport, for most people, for short daily journeys.

Our Mission
We help more people get cycling, to transform lives and the environment.

What we do
To achieve this, we:

 Offer people access to working bicycles
 Help people gain the skills and confidence to cycle wherever they want, whenever they want
 Offer extra support to anyone who faces barriers to unlock the benefits of cycling
 Strengthen the cycling sector: we train new bike mechanics, cycle instructors and partner with Local Authorities, businesses and other charities looking to boost cycling levels.

name: Adult Visual Impairment Friendly Rowing Sessions
description:
This session supports adults with a Visual impairment to learn how fixed seat rowing in a fun and supportive environment. Participants will row in a wooden gig or skiff which are designed for sea rowing, thus are very stable. There will a coach / instructor running each session, and sighted volunteers in each boat to guide participants if needed and describe surroundings.  The sessions involves some time orientating around the oar and boat and practising a good stroke for the first 20 minutes; then participants will row up Bristol Harbour which flows through the heart of the city.


It costs £6 per person and runs every Sunday from 11AM to 1PM.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: E-mail volunteering@allaboardwatersports.co.uk and we can book you in and give you all the information you need.

name: Advice, Groups & Support (BASS)
description:
Who we are

BASS Autism Services for Adults provide a service to adults with an Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and professionals and carers who support them.

There are allocated services for four geographical areas: Bristol, Bath and North East Somerset (BANES), North Somerset and South Gloucestershire.

The service has been running in Bristol since 2009, in 2013 the two spoke services in BANES and North Somerset started and in 2014 the service started in South Gloucestershire.

What we do

  • Assess and diagnose people who are referred to us by their GP.
  • Support colleagues in mental health services to work with individuals with ASD
  • Advice service with groups on mindfulness, stress management, social cognition and interaction, as well as an opportunity to book one to one sessions with our staff.
  • Social prescribing to help individuals with ASD to link with the community and access social opportunities.
  • Social support assessments for people accessing our post diagnostic services.
  • Post-diagnostic support - psycho-education, employment and benefits support, problem solving and signposting.
  • Training in Autism awareness ranging from one hour to full day training sessions.

We do not hold a caseload or care coordinate. We currently accept referrals for people within Bristol, North Somerset, BANES and South Gloucestershire. Referrals outside of these areas can be seen on a cost per case basis, subject to funding being agreed by the referring clinical commissioning group.

organization.name: Bristol Autism Spectrum Service
organization.description:
BASS Autism Services for Adults provide a service to adults with an Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and professionals and carers who support them.

There are allocated services for four geographical areas: Bristol, Bath and North East Somerset (BANES), North Somerset and South Gloucestershire.

The service has been running in Bristol since 2009, in 2013 the two spoke services in BANES and North Somerset started and in 2014 the service started in South Gloucestershire.

name: Age UK Bristol
description:
Age UK Bristol help make sure that everyone in Bristol can love later life. Age UK Bristol do this by supporting and empowering older people, helping other organisations to work together, and championing the interests of older people in the city. Providing impartial, free, and confidential Information & Advice to older people in Bristol for anyone over the age of 55 who lives or works in Bristol.

Age UK Bristol advisers are trained to offer people advice on all of the following issues: Money matters, benefits and allowances, including Pension Credit & Attendance Allowance Housing Council Tax Priority debts, such as rent & utility arrears, Social care services, care homes, lasting Power of Attorney, Wills and help completing forms .

They can also often advise on other issues, or signpost to other organisations if we are unable to help. Their Advice Line (0117 929 7537) is open Monday-Friday, 10am-4pm. If calling outside of those hours please leave a message and we will call you back as soon as we are able.

Other Services Provided: New Beginnings Day Centre provides a range of activities, good food, and transport for older people in South Bristol - 0117 987 8406.

Home Support enables older people to remain independent at home for longer by providing support with day to day tasks like cleaning and light cooking. This service also offers carers respite. Call 0117 987 8399 or email homesupport@ageukbristol.org.uk.

Friends Ageing Better - Join a community network of older people in Bristol where they can share what is happening locally and benefit from discounts from local businesses. 0117 440 4301.
Volunteering - We are always looking for people of all ages and backgrounds to help us run our services. For more information about volunteering with Age UK Bristol, call 0117 440 4305 or email volunteering@ageukbristol.org.uk.

Fees: Dependent on service.

organization.name: Age UK Bristol
organization.description: Age UK Bristol works to improve the lives of older people in Bristol through a range of different services.Age UK Bristol is an independent local charity, federated to Age UK (as a local partner) working together with and for older people locally, regionally and nationally.

name: Age UK South Gloucestershire
description:
Age UK South Gloucestershire works to make South Gloucestershire a county where older people feel empowered, respected, connected and enabled to make the very best of later life in communities that truly value, support and welcome them. We provide support to people over the age of 50 to receive the encouragement, opportunity and, where necessary, the care they need to make later life as fulfilling as it should be.

Age UK South Gloucestershire provides many services including Information and Advice on a variety of subjects including housing options, health, and local services, and benefits support where home visits are carried out to check to see if they are eligible for any extra financial support and then help them secure it.

Activity Day Centres centres in Downend, Filton, Thornbury and Warmley offer participants a varied and stimulating day in a safe setting away from home. 

Befriending links volunteer visitors with people who find themselves isolated or lonely and in need of a weekly home visit or telephone call and Reconnect matches individuals with another like-minded peer who has similar interests to them for social visits or outings. 

The Digital Inclusion Programme offer FREE in-home, one-to-one support so that you can make the most of digital technology and the internet! Whether you're a complete beginner or looking to brush up on your skills, our Digital Inclusion team is here to help! They can support you in using your gadget (tablet, smartphone or laptop) and help you learn new skills in a safe and secure way. 

Our FREE Tablet Loan Scheme is offered for those interested in exploring what the internet has to offer but who don’t have the technology to do so. We can provide you with a free loan tablet along with internet connectivity and support from our Digital Champions so that you can get online.

Improving Homes and Wellbeing is a pilot project between South Gloucestershire Council and Age UK South Gloucestershire to help and support homeowners whose homes have fallen into disrepair. It provides individuals with help and support to rectify this and identifies and helps address any underlying issues.

Our Walking Groups provide a flexible and accessible way to reintroduce physical activity into everyday life, and it has amazing benefits for our physical health as well as our mental well-being. It’s also a great way to meet new people and make new friends.

organization.name: Age UK South Gloucestershire
organization.description: Age UK South Gloucestershire is an independent local charity. We've been working in the local community to help older people for 20 years. We have 35 dedicated staff and over 220 volunteers helping us to deliver services and activities for older people in South Gloucestershire. Proud to have achieved the Organisational Quality Standards certification for local Age UKs in England.

name: Al-Anon Family Groups
description:
Al-Anon Family Groups UK & Eire is there for anyone whose life is or has been affected by someone else's drinking.

Our members provide meetings in all major towns and cities and are committed to being there for you when you need help. Whatever your relationship with the drinker, you will find other people who have similar stories to tell. You will realise that you are not alone. Listening to the shared experiences of others may help you find the confidence you need to deal with the effects of someone else's drinking. You will find it is possible to rediscover happiness, whether the alcoholic is still drinking or not.

Your anonymity is protected by using first names only. You will not be asked to reveal your surname or any other details about your identity or that of the drinker. Anything discussed within an Al-Anon meeting is treated as confidential, including your presence at the meeting.

We are widespread, with more than 700 groups throughout the UK and Eire alone. If getting to a meeting is not easy for you, you are welcome to join an online meeting. These are organised by the World Service Office (WSO) and accessible via the US website: https://www.al-anon.org 

Al-Anon meetings are free. We only accept donations from members towards running costs and literature so that we can be self-supporting. We only give what we can afford.

What we are not

Al-Anon is not a therapy group. We don't offer counselling or advice or try to explain your experiences.

We are not a religious organisation and welcome those of all faiths and none, treating everyone as equals. We discourage discussion about religion, politics and other outside topics.

name: Alcohol Support - NHS
description:
Useful contacts for alcohol problems

  • Drinkline is the national alcohol helpline. If you're worried about your own or someone else's drinking, you can call this free helpline in complete confidence. Call 0300 123 1110 (weekdays 9am to 8pm, weekends 11am to 4pm).
  • Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) is a free self-help group. Its "12 step" programme involves getting sober with the help of regular support groups.
  • Al-Anon Family Groups offers support and understanding to the families and friends of problem drinkers, whether they're still drinking or not. Alateen is part of Al-Anon and can be attended by 12- to 17-year-olds who are affected by another person's drinking, usually a parent.
  • We Are With You is a UK-wide treatment agency that helps individuals, families and communities manage the effects of drug and alcohol misuse. If you are over 50 and worried about your drinking, call 0808 8010 750
  • Adfam is a national charity working with families affected by drugs and alcohol. Adfam operates an online message board and a database of local support groups.
  • The National Association for Children of Alcoholics (Nacoa) provides a free, confidential telephone and email helpline for children of alcohol-dependent parents and others concerned about their welfare. Call 0800 358 3456 for the Nacoa helpline.
  • SMART Recovery groups help people decide whether they have a problem, build up their motivation to change, and offer a set of proven tools and techniques to support recovery.

Caring for an alcoholic? Find out where you can get support.

name: Alcoholics Anonymous - Bristol
description: Alcoholics Anonymous - Bristol Alcoholics Anonymous is a fellowship of men and women who share their experience, strength and hope with each other that they may solve their common problem and help others to recover from alcoholism. The only requirement for membership is a desire to stop drinking. There are no dues or fees for AA membership; they are self-supporting through their own contributions. AA is not allied with any sect, denomination, politics, organisation or institution; does not wish to engage in any controversy; neither endorses nor opposes any causes. Their primary purpose is to stay sober and help other alcoholics to achieve sobriety. Helpline operates 24 hours a day, 7 days a week

name: Alternative therapy
description:
I am a fully qualified EFT, Emotional Freedom Technique, Practitioner working on line from my home in Bristol. EFT is an amazing mind body technique with which you can release stuck negative emotions you might be holding on to within your energy system. It is often known as the emotional version of acupuncture but instead of using needles, you gently tap on meridian points on your head and body with your fingertips, while focusing on the negative emotion you wish to release. EFT is a remarkably quick, easy and effective way to resolve stress, anxiety, fears, phobias, trauma, performance issues, physical pain and much more! 
EFT has completely transformed my life and my greatest wish now is to work with others to help them transform their lives too.

Talking Point (http://forum.alzheimers.org.uk) is Alzheimer’s Society’s online support forum, for anyone affected by dementia. It’s open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and is a place to ask for advice, share information, and join in discussions.

organization.name: ANDYSMANCLUB
organization.description:
We are talking groups for men who have either been through a storm, are currently going through a storm or have a storm brewing in life.
On average one man every 2 hours takes his life in the UK. It’s often said a factor is that men don’t talk. That's why we were born to break down these stigmas. At ANDYSMANCLUB you don’t have to be suicidal or have a mental health problem, we just want to get men talking. We meet every Monday at 7PM, Except bank holidays

name: Ara Gambling Treatment Service
description: Ara been supporting problem gamblers and affected others across Bristol and the South West for many years, and in 2019 also became the National Gambling Treatment Service (NGTS) provider for the whole of Wales.  Ara offer free and confidential advice about gambling, together with one-to-one counselling for people experiencing problems with their own gambling, or that of a family member.

name: Ara Housing Service
description:
Ara, together with partners The Junction Project and The Salvation Army Bridge Project, provide a range of accommodation for people working on their recovery from substance misuse issues.  On offer is a diverse pathway providing safe accommodation to support recovery to independence.  Levels of housing include:

  • Prep intake housing – secure housing for people motivated to address their substance misuse issues
  • Prep housing – for people stable on substitute prescriptions
  • In Treatment housing – accommodation for people who have recently become abstinent from substitute prescribing, alcohol and non-prescribed drugs

To be eligible a client mist have a local connection with Bristol, and be homeless or at risk of homelessness.  All referrals need to go through Bristol City Council's Housing Support Register.  Contact us for more details

Helping you to achieve better health and wellbeing, no matter where you are starting from. It’s easier to make changes with someone cheering you on!

The outdoor areas include play facilities, picnic areas, art installations, an Amphitheatre, outdoor gym equipment, a measured mile for walking or running, and football and basketball nets.

Our main goal is to provide high quality services to prevent illness, promote good health and assist recovery after medical treatment. We are happy to answer any questions you may have and look forward to meeting you soon.

name: Art Therapeutic Community
description:
Studio Upstairs supports creative and personal recovery through arts practice. We provide an art therapeutic studio for adults (18+) where we offer membership to join a small group (around 10 people at a time) in person. This is aimed to support the group members mental health, wellbeing and artistic development. 

The Studio, a working arts community, exists to provide artistic resources and therapeutic support to people experiencing mental and emotional distress and to those in drug and alcohol recovery. We provide and maintain a working artists’ Studio, which is a community where people produce their own artwork - in whatever medium or format they determine - within a supervised, social, creative and therapeutic framework. We deliver flexible and considered artistic, educational and therapeutic support over the medium to long term. We advance public education by challenging the stigma surrounding mental health; this aim is attained through public exhibitions. high profile events and publications. Members attend on a regular weekly basis and are supported by qualified, registered and experienced arts professionals and therapists.

To find out more or submit a referral, please visit our website.

Telephone number: 07709 295 661

Email address: awp.bmhsanctuary@nhs.net

Opening times:  Thursday-Monday from 5pm-midnight at Gloucester House, Dorian Way, Southmead

Early intervention in psychosis -  The service is for anyone from the age of 14-65 experiencing the following:

  • Hearing voices or changes in their thoughts
  • Alterations in how events, people and thoughts are perceived
  • Feeling suspicious at times about other people
  • Experiencing beliefs and thoughts that cause the person distress
  • Changes in behaviour and performance, such as becoming more isolated or reduced motivation


Intensive Services -  Intensive Teams consist of experienced mental health staff who offer assessment and home treatment for people aged over 16 years experiencing a mental health crisis, as an alternative to hospital admission.

The team operates 24 hours a day 7 days a week. However, the team does not provide an 'emergency' service such as a 999 response.

name: Avon Gorge & Downs Wildlife Project
description:
The Avon Gorge & Downs Wildlife Project was launched in 1999. We were originally set up to secure the outstanding wildlife interest of the Bristol side of the Avon Gorge and Clifton and Durdham Downs and to raise awareness and understanding of this unique location and its importance for people and wildlife.

We are also working in partnership with the National Trust and Forestry England who manage Leigh Woods on the North Somerset side of the Gorge.

For information about wildlife, education sessions, events and reporting wildlife sightings on the Bristol side of the Avon Gorge, Clifton and Durdham Down, contact:

Vanessa Adnitt
Avon Gorge & Downs Biodiversity Education Officer
The Education Department, Bristol Zoo Gardens, Clifton, Bristol, BS8 3HA.
Telephone: 0117 903 0609
E: vadnitt@bristolzoo.org.uk

For information about the day-to-day running of the Downs and management on the Bristol side of the Gorge, contact:

Ben Skuse
Area supervisor Downs, Blaise, Kingsweston estates
Downs Rangers office, Clifton Down
Telephone: 01179736210
E-mail: ben.skuse@bristol.gov.uk

organization.name: Avon Gorge & Downs Wildlife Project
organization.description:
The Avon Gorge & Downs Wildlife Project was launched in 1999. We were originally set up to secure the outstanding wildlife interest of the Bristol side of the Avon Gorge and Clifton and Durdham Downs and to raise awareness and understanding of this unique location and its importance for people and wildlife.
The National Trust and Forestry England (who manage Leigh Woods and the North Somerset side of the Gorge) have also joined the Project steering group.
The group is made up of a partnership of organisations and focuses on surveying and monitoring, habitat management and education.

name: Bedminster Food Club
description:
Food clubs have been set up all over the city of Bristol and are a great way for people that are finding things tough financially to get a regular box of fresh, nutritious food at the same time as reducing food waste, and we hope it will also be a way of destigmatising food banks.

Our club runs weekly from the United Reform Church Hall on West Street in Bedminster and supports anyone locally that is economically vulnerable.

Annual membership is £1 and a bag of food worth £10-15 is available weekly for £3.50. There will be collection slots as part of the Covid secure measures in place.

To find out more about joining our food club please email  food@bs3community.org.uk

There are other established Food Clubs all over Bristol Speedwell, Redcliffe, Hartcliffe, St Pauls so if people want to find out where their nearest club is they can email Simon on Simon.green@family-action.org.uk

organization.name: BS3 Community
organization.description:
BS3 Community Development was founded in 1991 to improve the lives of people living in BS3 and the surrounding area. We run two community venues; the Southville Centre and the Chessel Centre.

BS3 Community Development is a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee and as a social business we reinvest surplus generated from our profitable services into educational, arts, environmental, health and wellbeing projects that we either run directly or support partners to deliver.

name: Befriending
description: Torch Trust - Bristol Befriending         Journeying with Befriending is a new scheme for Bristol, covering the BS3 area. We have trained volunteers, fully referenced and with DBS checks in place, who are available to befriend people experiencing sight loss. The aim is for a befriender to be matched with a client and to visit for approximately a 6 month period of time to listen and offer confidential emotional support, giving practical support in finding information and services locally and helping the individual to link up with ongoing support once the befriending period finishes. The befrienders have all had training involving sight loss awareness, listening skills, aspects of loss and grief, the impact of sight loss, safeguarding, etc. * This scheme is currently available in the BS3 area of Bristol only, but Torch Trust also has telephone befriending available for people in any area of the UK. All Torch Trust services have a Christian basis, but are open to people of all faiths or none. http://www.torchtrust.org/smartweb/Groups%20and%20Fellowship/torch-fellowship-groups

name: Beloved
description:
Beloved offers support to women working in massage parlours in Bristol and surrounding areas, and are affiliated with Beyond the Streets. 

We offer a friendly, non-judgemental and confidential service for women working in the indoor sex industry in Bristol. We value you as a woman and promote the dignity, health and wellbeing of all the women who access support through Beloved.

Do you need help with any of the following?

  • Someone to talk to, a friendly face or emotional support
  • Accommodation
  • Short term emergency financial assistance
  • Support with CV writing and job applications
  • Support to access benefits you may be eligible for
  • Support obtaining formal documents including passports, setting up bank accounts and accessing the EU settlement scheme
  • Local foodbank information


We distribute personal attack alarms, safety information, and signpost to local organisations such as specialist sexual health clinics, debt advice, housing support, mental health services and weekly friendship groups.

We visit the Bristol massage parlours where we are welcomed in, for a chat and to offer friendship and a listening ear. Each woman receives a goodie bag containing a cupcake, toiletries, safety information and other small gifts.

Teams of volunteers from various churches go out each month on a regular night, offering a friendly face, a listening ear and, if the women want, prayer.   

We also provide an online chat service and our trained staff are available at the end of the phone for those women who would like to continue the conversation.

name: Best Life Companions
description:
Our Mission
As a purpose led organisation, our mission is to improve the lives of adults after an injury, diagnosis or into their later years, in the community, through providing unrivalled independence support, whilst maintaining, high standards of social, physical and emotional well-being.

What we stand for
At Best Life Companions and Clubs, our core values are woven into the fabric of everything we do, guiding our mission to enhance the lives of individuals through meaningful connections and enriching experiences. 

Vibrancy pulses through our clubs, where we cultivate a vibrant atmosphere filled with engaging hobbies, stimulating interests, invigorating movement, and boundless fun, ensuring that every moment is infused with energy and vitality. 

Community lies at the heart of our approach, fostering a sense of belonging and nurturing genuine relationships within welcoming spaces imbued with kindness and inclusivity. 

We champion independence by promoting active engagement, fostering familiarity with our environment, and providing a consistent support system of trusted individuals, empowering each person to live life on their terms. 

Above all, we uphold dignity as a fundamental principle, treating every individual with the utmost respect, boundless compassion, meaningful involvement, and a sincere dedication to being truly person-centered in all aspects of our care. 

At Best Life, we are committed to embodying these values each day as we strive to create a community where everyone can thrive and find fulfillment.

Repeat Prescription requests which must be in writing
Online appointment booking, prescription requests and access to your medical record
Treatment Room: A team of nurses provide a range of services including minor injuries, wound care, blood tests, smoking cessation advice, blood pressure testing, cervical smears, ear syringing and travel clinics. To book an appointment please phone between 10am and 12 noon.
Baby clinics are held every Wednesday afternoon by Dr Farey or Dr Lewis for postnatal and baby checks although we can arrange appointments with equally experienced GPs on other days.

 

Drug and alcohol services
Specialist drug and alcohol services can be accessed through the surgery. Members of the practice follow the South Bristol Methadone Prescribing protocol. All patients receiving methadone on prescription must see a drugs worker. All consultations are confidential.
Immunisations

Childhood illnesses: we request you to bring your child to attend when they reach the age for their immunisation.
Flu jabs: we will invite you to attend for a flu immunisation if you are aged over 65 or have an illness that would be made worse if you caught flu.
Travel: if you are going abroad, you can arrange an appointment with a Treatment Room Nurse for advice on any immunisations you may require.

 

THE FOLLOWING SERVICES ARE PROVIDED AT BROOKLEA BY OTHER HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS

District Nurses working in the Community
Physiotherapy
Podiatry (foot care): If you have a problem with your feet, or an illness such as diabetes that can affect your feet, please contact reception for an appointment with the Podiatrist.
Midwives based at Brooklea
Health Visitors based at Brooklea

name: Blood Cancer UK
description:
We're here to beat blood cancer. We do this by funding research that take us closer to a cure. Right now, our community is funding 360 researchers across the UK who are searching for the next breakthrough. Our research has already helped transform treatments and taken us to the point where the day we will beat blood cancer is now in sight. Our researchers are working to finish the job.

As well as looking for a cure in the future, we help people right now. We’re there for people when they need someone to talk to, whether on the phone or online, and we offer health information people can trust, in a language they can understand.

We also campaign for change, helping make sure that people get the healthcare they deserve and that new treatments that come from research breakthroughs are available on the NHS.

How to contact us

You can call us free on 0808 2080 888 to speak to a member of our trained blood cancer support team in confidence. Our phone lines are open:

  • Monday: 10am–7pm
  • Tuesday to Friday: 10am–4pm
  • Saturday, Sunday and bank holidays: 10am–1pm

organization.name: Blood Cancer UK
organization.description:
We're here to beat blood cancer.

We fund world-class research, ensure everyone affected has access to the right support at the right time, and campaign for better treatments.

name: BLOOM - Music sessions for parents experiencing anxiety and depression
description:
BLOOM is a group that uses music and sound in a playful and safe way for mums and babies.

Created by Bristol Beacon in partnership with Bluebell care, BLOOM offers new parents an opportunity to make music, or just listen and absorb. Come to a session to relax, have fun, and learn new things to bring home with you.

No musical experience is needed, everyone is welcome.

What is Bluebell care?
Bluebell is a charity that support parents with their perinatal mental health and wellbeing.

‘Perinatal’ is a word that means ‘around birth’. So this means Bluebell works to provide emotional well-being during pregnancy and during the first year after birth.

All of Bluebell’s services are free, including the projects created in partnership with Bristol Beacon.

Sessions
Sessions are free, sign-up is required.

Mondays 10:00 – 12:00 (10 week term)
Session for parents and children under 2

Location: Bluebell Place, 2 Quay St, Bristol, BS1 2JL

description:
Coaching is a partnership where we uncover your

  • Doubts and shadows

  • History and future

  • Hidden layers

  • Your unspoken dreams

  • Strengths and natural gifts

name: Bluebird Care (Bristol)
description:
Our CQC Outstanding Bristol team put each customer's preferences, requirements and goals at the heart of their care service.

We treat our customers as we would treat our own family members, ensuring dignity, privacy, independence, growing confidence and involvement in their care. We see our customers for who they truly are, not as a list of care needs. Respecting their unique values and qualities gives us a valuable insight into their interesting, individual lives.   

Working collaboratively with our customers and their advocates, we steer clear of a one-size-fits all approach. Our bespoke plans evolve organically over time, giving you control over your journey in care.

From companionship to complex care, from reablement to palliative care, delivering Bristol's best care service is our passion. Our specialist team members are ready to assist. Contact our team to experience the Bluebird Care difference.

organization.name: Bluebird Care
organization.description:
We believe that care matters and we are committed to providing the highest quality home care so that our customers can remain in their own homes.
What makes our homecare services different is that we put you first. We aim to provide you with the same standard of care that we would expect for our own families. This means valuing each person’s unique qualities and seeing them as an individual, and not as a list of care needs.

We work alongside families and individuals to tailor our services to help our customers stay in control of their own care for as long as they are able to. Delivering the very best homecare is our passion, and we strive to achieve this every day.

name: Bluebird Care (South Gloucestershire)
description:
Bluebird Care (South Gloucestershire) believe that care matters and we are committed to providing the highest quality homecare across South Gloucestershire so that our customers can remain in their own homes. We deliver homecare and support services from our headquarters in Chipping Sodbury.

Bluebird Care aim to provide you with the same standard of care that you would expect for your own families. This means valuing each person’s unique qualities and seeing them as an individual, and not as a list of care needs.

They work alongside families and individuals to tailor our services to help our customers stay in control of their own care for as long as they are able to. Delivering the very best homecare is our passion, and we strive to achieve this every day.

name: Borderlands
description:
We are a Christian charity based in Bristol that exists to work with refugees, asylum seeker and other vulnerable migrants to help them from exclusion to belonging. 

We support refugees, asylum seekers and those with insecure immigration status to alleviate poverty and hardship.

We create a community of welcome where we support people on their way of securing 'leave to remain' and enhance social inclusion and well-being.

We raise awareness of the needs and experiences of our members among the wider community.

We work with people regardless of race, disability, sex, age, religious belief or sexual orientation. We have a vision for a world where refugees and asylum seekers can seek sanctuary and justice, can make full use of their talents and abilities, feel valued for their contributions, and build worthwhile lives.

name: Bradley Stoke Green Gyms
description:
TCV Green Gym is a scheme which inspires you to improve both your health and the environment at the same time. Experienced leaders guide you through a range of practical projects, giving you the opportunity to tackle physical jobs in the outdoors - improving your strength and stamina, boosting your practical skills and confidence and benefiting your local green spaces. Green Gyms are particularly suitable for those suffering from or recovering from long physical or mental illnesses, for the elderly or the unemployed.

Here in Bradley Stoke the Three Brooks Nature Conservation Group hold a weekly Green Gym each Thursday from 10am to about 1pm. They are always accompanied by trained leaders and first aiders and include tea and biscuits. All Bradley Stoke Green Gyms meet in the security compound at the rear of the Leisure Centre. All you need to do is turn up. You will be warmly welcomed. 

Links: Green Gym contact details; Green Gym website; BBC Radio 4 Woman's Hour item; BBC web article; Green Gym poster; 2011 Green Gym Programme. 2012 Green Gym Programme 2013 Green Gym Programme 2015 Green Gym Programme

name: Bradley Stoke Leisure Centre
description:
Bradley Stoke recently underwent a £3.6m redevelopment. The gym now features the very latest in strength and conditioning equipment, whilst BodyTone, our new toning suite is aimed at customers who prefer a full body workout using gentle, repetitive movements. Our 3 large fitness studios enable us to offer an extensive fitness class programme, which features Les Mills classes and includes studio cycling and Yoga.

FACILITIES

  • Large fully kitted out Gym
  • 4 Large Fitness Studios
  • 25m Main Swimming Pool (includes pool hoist)
  • 10m Small Pool
  • 4 Badminton Court Main Hall
  • BodyTone toning table’s suite
  • Xheight Adventure Climb (Temporarily closed)
  • Explore Adventure Play (Temporarily closed)
  • SOHO Coffee Co (Temporarily closed)
  • Outside Children's Play Area (Temporarily closed)
  • 4 Meeting Rooms
  • A range of Accessibility Equipment and Changing Facilities
  • Library
  • In Trim Hair Salon
  • Bradley Stoke Physiotherapy
  • Botanical Beauty
  • Parking with electric recharge station

ACCESSIBILITY FOR OUR DISABLED CUSTOMERS

Bradley Stoke offers the following facilities:

  • Dedicated parking spaces for disabled badge holders
  • Where height adjustable changing stretchers are provided full room hoist coverage is given with overhead tracking systems for use with customer’s own slings.
  • Accessible Toilet
  • Dedicated disabled changing room
  • Height adjustable changing table (poolside and dry-side)
  • Poolside hoist
  • Lift to 2nd floor

Our Centres are inclusive to all.  If you have a specific requirement and need further assistance please contact us on 03003330300 and we will try our best to help you.

Bradley Stoke Active Lifestyle Centre,
Fiddlers Wood Lane,
Bradley Stoke,
BS32 9BS

organization.name: Circadian Trust/Active Lifestyles
organization.description:
We are Circadian Trust; an innovative, social enterprise operating as an independent charity, which successfully manages leisure facilities across South Gloucestershire.
We run and operate our 5 Active Lifestyle Centres, to bring our mission ‘Inspiring Active Lifestyles’ to life.

name: Brandon Trust
description:
The Brandon Trust provides individualised, high-quality support that is genuinely life-enhancing. This ranges from light-touch enabling services through to long-term residential care for people with complex needs. Headquartered in Bristol, we operate across the south of England and south Midlands, from London through Warwickshire to Cornwall. Our support is designed and delivered by a staff team of over 2,000 and underpinned by our values. 

We are committed to working with the people we support, and those who surround them, to shape a future where every person with a learning disability will be empowered to live their life to its full potential.

name: Breathe for Wellbeing
description:
A FREE six week course  to support people over the age of 55 who are feeling low, sad, fearful, anxious, panicky, tired, or lonely in responses to the Pandemic. This course is sponsored by St. Monica's Trust.

This Breathe for Wellbeing course is for up to 15 people and will be delivered in a friendly, COVID-safe and supportive face to face environment over six weeks (two hours per week).

It’s not a ‘drop-in’ course – we hope that you’ll come each week for continuity as well as to create a little community.

Next Courses:

The Greenway Centre (Southmead): starting 3 May 2022, 2-4pm

Knowle West Healthy Living Centre: Starting 4 May 2022, 4-6pm

contact NCIM to book: enquiries@ncim.org.uk / 0117 370 1875

name: Brigstowe
description: Brigstowe’s vision is a world in which people living with HIV live long and healthy lives, free from poverty, stigma, prejudice and discrimination.  Brigstowe’s mission is to enhance the quality of life for people living with HIV.  They offer many HIV services such as 1 to 1 advice and support, peer support and also a migrant and asylum service.

name: Bristol After Stroke
description:
We provide:

  • Information and guidance - wherever you are on your stroke journey
  • Emotional and psychological support - for you and your loved ones
  • Peer support and opportunites of meet others with similar experiences
  • Rehabilitation support
  • Care for the carers

Stroke is a long-term condition and people can continue to see improvements up to five, or even ten year later. Bristol After Stroke is building a community of support for everyone affected by stroke in our area.

organization.name: Bristol After Stroke
organization.description: Bristol After Stroke Bristol After Stroke. formerly known as Bristol After Stroke Foundation works across Bristol and South Gloucestershire supporting people affected by stroke. We are a local charity that can help those affected by a stroke adjust to the changes in their life after a stroke.

name: Bristol Autism Spectrum Service
description: Bristol Autism Spectrum Service BASS Autism Services for Adults provide a service to adults with autism spectrum conditions (ASCs) and professionals and carers who support them. What we do: Assess and diagnose people who are referred to us by their GP. Support colleagues in mental health services to assess and diagnose. Social support assessments to people who have been diagnosed by our team. Advice service with groups on mindfulness, managing anxiety, social cognition and interaction, as well as an opportunity to book one to one sessions with our staff (see details below). Post-diagnostic support - psycho-education, coping strategies and signposting. Training in Asperger syndrome and ASCs ranging from one hour awareness sessions to a full day's training. We are a small team and therefore do not have capacity to carry a caseload or do direct 1:1 support. We currently accept referrals for people within Bristol, North Somerset, BANES and South Gloucestershire. We run advice services for adults with autism diagnoses in Bristol, Bath, South Gloucestershire and North Somerset. Bristol autism advice service runs every Friday from 12.30 - 4.30pm at the Create Centre, Spike Island. It is open to people with autism spectrum conditions who live in the area. BaNES autism advice service runs every Wednesday afternoon from 1.00 - 5.00pm at the Percy Community Centre, Bath. North Somerset autism advice service runs every second Wednesday of the month, from 12.30 - 4.30pm at 1in4, Weston-super-Mare. South Gloucestershire autism advice service runs on Friday afternoons from 1.30 - 4.00pm at the Armadillo Cafe, Yate. For further information please contact Gemma Allen: Telephone: 01275 796204 Email: awp.bass@nhs.net mailto:awp.bass@nhs.net

organization.name: Bristol Autism Spectrum Service
organization.description:
BASS Autism Services for Adults provide a service to adults with an Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and professionals and carers who support them.

There are allocated services for four geographical areas: Bristol, Bath and North East Somerset (BANES), North Somerset and South Gloucestershire.

The service has been running in Bristol since 2009, in 2013 the two spoke services in BANES and North Somerset started and in 2014 the service started in South Gloucestershire.

name: Bristol Autism Support
description: Bristol Autism Support Bristol Autism Support (BAS) is a not-for-profit Social Enterprise providing information, support and training for parents and carers of autistic children in Bristol, North Somerset and South Gloucestershire. What we do We create a wide range of opportunities for parents and carers of children with autism to connect with each other. Our strong community helps give parents and carers the knowledge needed to help them better support the children they look after. We provide clear, relevant information about autism to parents and carers. By doing so, we hope to improve the futures and outcomes of autistic children. We use this website, our Facebook page and email to signpost information about local and national services and support. As much as possible, we share the voices of autistic adults because we know they are best placed to teach us about our children. We work with local venues and attractions to make public places more accessible for families with autistic children. We provide volunteering and work experience opportunities that enable parents, carers and autistic young people to gain skills and improve confidence. Our structure BAS is an Unincorporated Association, which means we exist to serve the local autism family community. It also means any money that we raise or that is donated is spent solely on events, activities or things that will help families affected by autism in Bristol and surrounding areas. We have strong values. Our funding comes from private individual donations and grants. We have a core team of decision makers that runs the organisation. We are not a charity, and we are not council funded. This means we can act quickly to create new opportunities to support families with autistic children, either diagnosed or undiagnosed, regardless of the area where they live. For a full list of our 2019 support group meetings, please visit: https://www.bristolautismsupport.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/BAS-2019-meetings-schedule.pdf https://www.bristolautismsupport.com/events/ https://www.facebook.com/bristolautismsupport/ http://eepurl.com/ds7Pw1 https://www.bristolautismsupport.com/about-us/bristol-autism-support-values/ https://www.bristolautismsupport.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/BAS-2019-meetings-schedule.pdf

name: Bristol Avon Rivers Trust
description:
Bristol Avon Rivers Trust (BART) is a charity which delivers education, land and river management advice and practical river restoration work throughout the Bristol Avon catchment.

We aim to re-connect communities to their local rivers and help them to better appreciate and improve them for the benefit of people and wildlife.

BART aims to conserve and enhance the status of our waterbodies for current and future generations.

The Bristol Avon Catchment is a unique and beautiful network of rivers, streams and lakes, with the Bristol Avon at its heart. Stretching 75 miles from its source in Wiltshire, to its confluence with the River Severn in Bristol, the River Avon and its tributaries are the lifeblood of the area and they are under constant threat.

Bristol Avon Rivers Trust (BART) is working hard to protect our rivers for the benefit of people and wildlife.

name: Bristol Black Carers
description:
Bristol Black Carers Bristol Black Carers provides culturally-appropriate support and services to the Black and Ethnic Minority (BME) carers in Bristol. Through our work we strive to reduce enduring health and social care inequalities.

We carry out extensive outreach work within BME communities to identify needs; we work with a range of diverse communities and different faith and cultural groups. Our outreach work enables us to meet the individual needs of our service users and ensure they have the support they need.

Our development work also helps us to identify needs that aren't being met, help community groups to develop appropriate services, and to give support to isolated Black Carers in the community.

SERVICES:- Advice & Information: - Includes one-to-one support and advocacy on issues affecting BME carers. Telephone service and drop-in during office hours. E.g. form filling support Carers Wellbeing Service: - Provides support through peer groups, home visits, training events, complimentary health treatments and outings. Young Carers Service: - Supports and empowers young black carers through one-to-one casework and by arranging lots of exciting events, workshops and trips. These include fun workshops, outings, activities and a regular youth club.

Sensory Support Service

Sensory Impairment Team - Independence Support for Disabled People

  The Sensory Impairment Team is part of Adult Social Care, Bristol City Council. They are a citywide team, working with Bristol citizens who are aged over 18 and are Deaf, Hard of Hearing, Deafened, Deafblind or Visually Impaired. The Sensory Impairment Team provide support, advice and rehabilitation services in Bristol in line with the Care Act 2014, as well as offering Care Act assessments to those who may have longer term needs for care and support. As a multi-professional team, they are committed to supporting Bristol citizens to maximise their independence and achieve their goals.

Drop-in service

The Sensory Impairment Team offer an in-person drop-in service 2x weekly for citizens to access support with regards to:

  • Translating letters, emails or written information to BSL
  • To support with phoning and booking appointments
  • To support with paying for bills and services
  • To support with finding information and getting referrals to other services

Wednesdays  1.30pm – 3.30pm @ Centre for Deaf and Hard of Hearing People (Vassall Centre, Gill Avenue, BS16 2QQ)

Fridays 1:30pm – 3:30pm @ Bedminster Library (Bedminster Parade, BS3 4AQ)

For further information about the drop-ins please email sensory.impairment@bristol.gov.uk / SMS 07775 646 671

For a referral for vision rehabilitation, equipment assessment (vision) or social work input, contact Care Direct on 0117 922 2700 / adult.care@bristol.gov.uk / Adult Care Referral Form (bristol.gov.uk)

organization.name: Bristol City Council
organization.description:
Bristol City Council is the local authority of Bristol, England. The council is a unitary authority, and its executive function is controlled by a directly elected mayor of Bristol. Bristol has 35 wards, electing a total of 70 councillors. 
The main services offered by the Council are: Adult Social Care Services, Bins, recycling and street maintenance, 
Business rates, Bus passes and disabled parking permits, Children and families services, Citizen Service Points: face-to-face, Council housing, Council tax, Customer services centre, Electoral services, Highways, Home Choice Bristol, Homelessness prevention, Housing benefit and council tax reduction, Jobs and recruitment, Leisure, Libraries, Pest control and dog wardens, pollution and public safety, Planning and building regulations, Register office, Residents' parking permits, Schools, Transport & Streets, Press, public relations and media (PR)

General enquiries (main switchboard) Call: 0117 922 2000
Phone lines are open 8.30am to 5pm Monday to Thursday, 8.30am to 4.30pm Friday.
Contact details for each individual department can be found at: www.bristol.gov.uk/contact

For Deaf people only
Contact us using BSL interpreter or by using Textphone, Texbox or Texmee.

Sign Video BSL interpreting Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm, you'll need a computer or laptop with a webcam, tablet or smartphone and a broadband connection or a 3G/4G data plan on your mobile device
Textphone 0208 964 6345
