name: Chance to Shine Street
description:
We deliver free cricket sessions in different areas with the aim of using cricket as a tool to increase aspirations, mutual respect and enhance relationships with others, including schools and the wider community.

The sessions, which are inclusive to people of all backgrounds and abilities, are created so that all equipment is provided and can be played easily to include everyone.

St Bede's Catholic College - Monday 6-8pm (please email to find out the age group sessions).

Hengrove Park Leisure Centre - Tuesday 5-7pm (please email to find out the age group sessions).

City Academy Bristol - Sunday 1-6pm (please email to find out the age group sessions).

name: Changes Bristol
description:
Changes Bristol provide peer support groups in Bristol and online for anyone aged 18 or over, offering a safe and friendly space for people to share any worries they might have. Our groups are free to access, confidential, with no referral needed and no diagnosis required. We also now offer one-to-one phone befriending for new and existing members.

As well as this support, we offer a large number of volunteering opportunities and workplace training in mental health awareness.

Click here for details on support groups available.

organization.name: Changes Bristol
organization.description:
Our Support
We understand that no-one should have to face feelings of stress, anxiety or depression alone.

That’s why Changes Bristol provide peer support groups in Bristol and online for anyone aged 18 or over, offering a safe and friendly space for people to share any worries they might have. Our groups are free to access, confidential, with no referral needed and no diagnosis required. We also now offer one-to-one phone befriending for new and existing members.

As well as this support, we offer a large number of volunteering opportunities and workplace training in mental health awareness.

name: Changes Mental Health Support Group - Women Only
description:
Changes Mental Health Support Group - Women Only
Our meetings are for adults (anyone over the age of 18) suffering from a range of mental health conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, bipolar disorder, social anxiety, personality disorders, self-harming or mood swings, to name just a few. If you are suffering from any form of mental illness, and are able to converse with people, you are welcome to attend our meetings.
You do not require a referral from your GP, you can just turn up on the day. Feel free to call us at the office if you would like to speak to a friendly voice before coming along, our tel no is 0117 941 1123 and email info@changesbristol.org.uk
Our service is not an alternative to other treatments but is there to complement many of the other services provided by statutory bodies.
This meeting is for women only and is run in partnership with Missing Link.

Our Support
We understand that no-one should have to face feelings of stress, anxiety or depression alone.

That’s why Changes Bristol provide peer support groups in Bristol and online for anyone aged 18 or over, offering a safe and friendly space for people to share any worries they might have. Our groups are free to access, confidential, with no referral needed and no diagnosis required. We also now offer one-to-one phone befriending for new and existing members.

As well as this support, we offer a large number of volunteering opportunities and workplace training in mental health awareness.

name: CHAS (Bristol) Housing Advice Service
description:
CHAS (Bristol) Housing Advice Service

Focusing on tackling issues of homelessness and unsuitable housing, CHAS is a charity dedicated to providing lasting solutions to people in housing crisis. By providing high quality housing advice and support, we aim to improve lives in the Bristol community.

CHAS provides free, independent and confidential advice on housing and related matters, to anyone in housing need in Bristol and the surrounding area. We typically operate our service by telephone and before COVID-19 we would also carry out home visits and outreach sessions, we are slowly beginning to increase outreach sessions, most notably with our BOOST Friday morning sessions held at Barton Hill Settlement.

CHAS provides high quality casework that achieves positive outcomes for its service users. Our main focus is helping people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, or living in unsuitable / unsafe accommodation and in need of rehousing. Although we help anyone in housing need, we prioritise those who are most vulnerable or who have had difficulty accessing other advice services. We advise on issues such as homelessness and the threat of homelessness, housing benefit, rent arrears, landlord & tenant problems, private renting, possession action by landlords and security of tenure, housing conditions & disrepair, overcrowding, noise & neighbour nuisance, housing & relationship breakdown, domestic violence, racial and other types of harassment, applications for social housing and supported accommodation.

Our Advice Workers endeavour to work with people until the situation is resolved. If CHAS is unable to resolve a particular issue we will help our client to access a service that can help them. As a small service we cannot always answer the phone but please do leave a voicemail as we pick them up regularly.

CHAS (Bristol) Housing Advice Service

name: Children and Young Peoples' services
description:
Our experts can help you to live actively, independently and well with sight loss. Whether you're asking for yourself, a member of your family, or your child, speak to someone from our friendly team today for more information.

Family support

Our team is here to give advice and emotional support from the moment your child is diagnosed with a vision impairment. Our experts can share their experience to build your whole family's knowledge and confidence and provide tools that are right for your child's specific needs.

Education support

Our specialist team can offer independent and tailored advice to help your child receive the educational support they are entitled to. From supporting you when you are choosing the right nursery, school or college, to working with teachers and special education staff or advising on assistive technologies.

Technology grants and sensory toys

For children with sight loss, technology and sensory play is vital. Our expert team can provide personalised advice to help you choose the right technology or sensory toys for your child's age and stage. We can offer grants to help buy the specialist technology or sensory equipment your child needs. We also have a range of sensory packages with toys carefully selected by our experts for different age ranges. (Subject to availability).

My Life Skills

We're here to help your child learn invaluable practical skills for life. From supporting physical development and learning in the early years, to navigating streets safely, preparing food, handling money, using technology and managing their appearance they grow older.

My Time to Play

My Time to Play helps children aged 0-4 with a vision impairment develop through play and provides parents with the opportunity to network, share experiences and pick up skills and knowledge to support their child's development with confidence.

CustomEyes Books

CustomEyes Books are for everyone aged 0-25 with a vision impairment, or dyslexia. Whatever reading format your child needs, we'll tailor their books to meet their individual requirements font type and size, line spacing, paper colour and more. What's more, if the book they want isn't already on our catalogue of over 4,200 titles, we'll do our best to add it. All books are available at the recommended retail price, regardless of format.

Family Events

Guide Dogs family events are a great day out where your family can relax and have fun together - and meet other families with similar stories. They allow children with a vision impairment to build confidence and make lifelong friends.

Buddy Dogs

Our buddy dogs bring a new friend into the lives of children with sight loss. By helping to develop their self-confidence, improve relationships and build a greater sense of trust, these dogs can have a hugely positive effect on your child's wellbeing - and your family, too.

How do you access the service?

Families can self-refer or be referred by a professional.

name: Chinese Community Wellbeing Society
description:
The Chinese Community Wellbeing Society exists to support the health and social care needs of the Chinese community across the southwest of England.

We provide general advice, support and information to the Chinese and the south east Asian community.

Services are normally offered during our office hours – Monday to Friday, 9:00am to 5:00pm – with the exception of some cultural & social activities, which can take place on evenings or weekends.

The Casework Surgery is run on certain days and by appointment only. Please click here for further details.

Additionally, we also run a Freephone helpline called the Chinese Lantern Project. This helpline covers many different subjects and is available to all members of the Chinese community in the South West region. The phone line is open from 10am-4pm, Mon-Fri. Please see here for further details.

The Group is able to provide a wide range of services for Chinese women and their families. These include:

  • Providing a care support service for the elderly, infirm and disabled
  • Providing a casework service
  • Counselling
  • Translation and interpreting
  • Help in fighting racial harassment and discrimination
  • Making referrals for help and advice on legal and immigration issues
  • Liaising on their behalf with statutory and voluntary agencies
  • Running a drop-in day centre
  • Helping to break down social isolation
  • Providing information on education, employment and enterprise training
  • Providing information and advice on health matters
  • Providing help and advice on housing and benefits
  • Fighting for the provision of housing schemes for the elderly
  • Running English classes
  • Providing information on crime prevention
  • Providing training for employment
  • Running cultural and social trips

Main phone: 0117 935 1462
Email: admin@chinesecws.org.uk

Helpline
Phone: 0808 802 0012
Email: helpline@chinesecws.org.uk

Other services:

Care support:
0117 955 3330

Casework surgery:
0117 955 4486

name: Chinese Lantern Project
description: Chinese Lantern Project The Chinese Lantern Project is a free and confidential telephone helpline service for the Chinese community in the South West region. They provide information and signposting to specialist national and local sources of help on issues such as: benefits, housing, debt, employment, training, social care, family, discrimination as well as immigration. The aim is to identify isolated and hidden members of the Chinese community and empower them to better integrate into the wider society. Fees: Calls are free from all UK landlines and UK mobile networks

name: Choices 4 U
description:
Choices 4 U

Choices 4 U provide day opportunities for people with learning difficulties from the age of 16. Support is adapted that enables people with learning difficulties to become more connected to their community, achieve learning and employment aspirations and access meaningful social and leisure interests that promote good health and wellbeing to lead a fulfilling life.

Choices 4 U can support people to:

  • learn independent living skills
  • lead a healthy lifestyle
  • develop friendships
  • think about getting into work and get support on how to do this

For more information on Choices 4 U and how to get involved please contact us.

organization.name: Choices 4 U
organization.description:
Choices 4 U
Choices 4 U

name: Christmas Cheer
description:
Christmas day can be a particularly difficult day for people experiencing loneliness.  Christmas Cheer brings together volunteers and isolated members of the community, to share time, food and smiles on Christmas day at a variety of venues across the Bristol, South Glos and North Somerset region.  Guests are collected by our volunteers and together go to a venue for a Christmas lunch, joining others to share a special few hours.

If you know someone who could benefit, who meets the criteria below, please get in touch!

  • Aged over 50* (if younger please get in touch to discuss)

  • Living in Bristol, North Somerset or South Gloucestershire

  • Living alone and in own home

  • No-one else to share Christmas day with

  • Feeling lonely

  • Not currently receiving other social prescribing support (for Marmalade Companions project)

  • Not in an active mental health crisis

Or if you can help as a volunteer, let us know!

description:
Join us for a Christmas Party. There will be entertainment, food and Christmas fun. 

Booking Essential

name: Cinnamon Trust
description:
What is the Cinnamon Trust?

A network of 18,000 volunteers “hold hands” with owners to provide vital loving care for their pets. We keep them together – for example, we’ll walk a dog every day for a housebound owner, we’ll foster pets when owners need hospital care, we’ll fetch the cat food, or even clean out the bird cage, etc.

When staying at home is no longer an option, our Pet Friendly Care Home Register lists care homes and retirement housing happy to accept residents with pets, and providing previous arrangements have been made with us we will take on life time care of a bereaved pet.

organization.name: Cinnamon Trust
organization.description: The Trust’s primary objective is to respect and preserve the treasured relationship between owners and their pets. To this end it works in partnership with owners to overcome any difficulties that might arise. A national network of over 18,000 community service volunteers has been established to provide practical help when any aspect of day to day care poses a problem – for example, walking the dog for a housebound owner.

name: Circadian Trust Leisure Centres - Accessibility
description:
Our aim is to make our Centres inclusive to everyone:   

  • Our pools are accessible to everyone, every day.  In addition, we also offer set sessions for people with disabilities.

  • Our gyms are accessible to everyone aged 11years+ (and at secondary school).  We offer a range of equipment which has been designed or adapted for people with different levels of mobility.  

  • We also run social sessions and groups such as MS, Parkinson and Osteoarthritis classes.   

  • We also support Team GB Paralympic athletes through our Springboard programme.  To view athletes who train with Active Lifestyle Centres please click here.

BRADLEY STOKE

  • Dedicated parking spaces for disabled badge holders 

  • Where height adjustable changing stretchers are provided full room hoist coverage is given with overhead tracking systems for use with customer’s own slings. 

  • Accessible Toilet 

  • Dedicated disabled changing room 

  • Height adjustable changing table (poolside and dry-side) 

  • Poolside hoist  

  • Lift to 2nd floor 

KINGSWOOD

  • Dedicated parking spaces for disabled badge holders 

  • Where height adjustable changing stretchers are provided full room hoist coverage is given with overhead tracking systems for use with customer’s own slings. 

  • Lift to lower floors 

  • Dedicated disabled changing room (poolside) 

  • Mobile hoist

organization.name: Circadian Trust/Active Lifestyles
organization.description:
We are Circadian Trust; an innovative, social enterprise operating as an independent charity, which successfully manages leisure facilities across South Gloucestershire.
We run and operate our 5 Active Lifestyle Centres, to bring our mission ‘Inspiring Active Lifestyles’ to life.

name: Citizens Advice Bureau (CAB) - Bristol
description:
We are a local charity that aims to provide free, independent, impartial and confidential advice to whoever may need it.

More about us

Bristol Bristol Citizens Advice Bureau is an independent charity that provides free, impartial advice and information on a range of issues. We can help with most everyday problems from benefits, employment to housing and debt. Before using our service we would encourage you to visit our national website www.citizensadvice.org.uk where you will find information about all the main areas of advice including: Benefits, Debt, Housing, Employment, Consumer, Family etc.  

Contact us on our national advice line:
Freephone 0808 278 7957 
Textphone (for the hard of hearing) 0800 144 88 84

Lines are open Monday – Friday, from 9:30 am to 4 pm.

name: Civil Service Pensioners' Alliance
description:
We are here to make sure you get the best from your retirement. We have been campaigning on behalf of pensioners in the UK for over 60 years. We also provide a whole host of member services and benefits designed to meet the needs of pensioners, from special deals on travel insurance to a computer helpline.

A dynamic membership
With over 50,000 members and local groups throughout England and Wales and separate branches in Malta, Northern Ireland and Scotland we are a powerful voice for pensioners. Members directly feed into our policy agenda through our annual general meeting.

name: Cleaning Service
description:
A Clean Sweep Cooperative are a professional cleaning service with a difference – we are a workers’ co-operative run and owned by adults with learning disabilities and we are proud to be the longest running business of its kind in the UK (as far as we know!).

We are an ethical employer concerned with protecting the environment and offer to use environmentally friendly cleaning products upon your request. Our professional and enthusiastic staff work in a diverse range of workplaces offering regular cleaning services tailored to your needs.

To receive a quote or to find out more please do get in touch.

name: Community Security Trust (CST)
description: Community Security Trust (CST) is a charity that protects British Jews from antisemitism, hate crimes and related threats.

name: Community Transport
description: We provide community transport for people that cannot access public transport. If you or someone you know needs help to get to the shops, to GP appointments, the dentist, hospital appointments, hairdressers and they live within our area then give us a call. You may have a mobility problem, need a supportive travel environment, have no access to a public bus or find it too far to walk to one, if you're unsure if you can use us, just give us a call and we can go through it together. We also do monthly Friends of GCT Trips.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: We can also post and email registration forms to people

organization.name: BS3 Community
organization.description:
BS3 Community Development was founded in 1991 to improve the lives of people living in BS3 and the surrounding area. We run two community venues; the Southville Centre and the Chessel Centre.

BS3 Community Development is a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee and as a social business we reinvest surplus generated from our profitable services into educational, arts, environmental, health and wellbeing projects that we either run directly or support partners to deliver.

name: Complaints Procedure Advocacy
description:
This service provides free, independent, confidential help to people who want to complain about social care services in Bristol.

If you wish to make a complaint about social care services provided by Bristol City Council you would need to be referred to us by The Advocacy People on 0330 4409000 or info@theadvocacypeople.org.uk

We provide self-help packs for anyone who simply needs information about how to complain, please download them from this webpage: Complaints Procedure Advocacy - The Care Forum - Advocacy

organization.name: The Care Forum
organization.description:
The Care Forum is an independent voluntary and community sector organisation, celebrating over 20 years of achieving better outcomes for people using health and social care services.

We work across Bath and North East Somerset, Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire and Swindon. We can also work across the South West.

name: Complementary Therapy Directory
description:
We promote the benefits of complementary therapy and aim to give visitors all the information they need to help them make an informed decision about whether therapy would be right for them.

The website has an FAQ's section, a number of useful articles written by our members and the facility to search for a practitioner in your area.

To ensure the professionalism of our website, all listed therapists have provided us with qualifications and insurance cover or proof of membership with a professional body.

Opening hours:
Monday - Friday
10am to 4pm

name: Coniston Community Centre and Cafe
description:
During bank holidays, opening times may vary so please check the organisation’s website for updates

There is so much on offer at the Centre from room and equipment hire, to a wide variety of classes and activities, theme nights, computer access and assistance, and even a tutoring service!

The centre is open 7 days a week and can cater for meetings, fitness & dance classes, parties, photoshoots, art groups, personal training sessions, performance rehearsals and so much more.

You can have a look at what's on offer here.

The community centre is also home to the Coniston Café where you can enjoy good food at low prices. All profits from the café go directly back into our charity work, so you can enjoy good food at the same time as raising money to benefit your local community.

The café is open 8:00am – 2:30pm Monday – Friday with a varied menu of full breakfasts, snacks, hot meals and drinks. All available at a low cost and prepared to order.

The café is also home to our Community Fridge where we have supplied food to those in need of a little extra help for over 3 years! We hate to see things go to waste and we know how tough it can be out there, so we strive to make sure no family gets left behind.

organization.name: Coniston Community Centre
organization.description:
Welcome to Coniston Community Centre. Your vibrant and friendly meeting place at the heart of Patchway.

We are dedicated to providing a welcoming, dynamic and supportive environment to the communities of Patchway and the surrounding areas.

There is so much on offer at the Centre from room and equipment hire, to a wide variety of classes and activities, theme nights, computer access and assistance, and even a tutoring service!

The centre is open 7 days a week and can cater for meetings, fitness & dance classes, parties, photoshoots, art groups, personal training sessions, performance rehearsals and so much more.

name: Coproduce Care CIC
description: Coproduce Care started out of frustration that a lot of the decisions being made in social care are carried out behind closed doors and from the top down, leaving out the majority of those affected by or working in such a key part of our communities. This includes people looking after friends or relatives, night staff, care co-ordinators, SME care providers, those looking for care for a friend or loved one. Also anyone in the general public curious about how the health and social care system works.

name: Core Process Psychotherapy
description: I am a registered UKCP and ACPP trainee psychotherapist and all my work is supervised by an accredited supervisor. My practice is Core Process Psychotherapy, a mindfulness based approach that slowly helps you to get in touch with your body, balancing both mind and body. I offer an 30 min intro session free of charge and affordable rate of £30 for an hour session. I practice at the Practice Rooms in Southville, Stokes Croft and Westbury on Trim. Please get in touch for more information.

organization.name: Ana Corral Psychotherapy
organization.description:
I started my own spiritual journey years ago when I was experiencing difficulties in life that left me feeling depressed and without any sense of direction. At that time I found my spiritual path, the Naqshbandi Sufi lineage, and my spiritual teacher Llewellyn Vaughan-Lee. This path, in combination with therapy, helped me to reconnect with myself.

After that period I decided to train as a psychotherapist to help others. I chose to train in Core Process Psychotherapy because I believe any healing journey is a spiritual one, that must be undertaken with a psycho-spiritual approach. At the moment I am a Senior trainee psychotherapist, studying for accreditation at the Karuna Institute, and am offering these sessions whilst completing my training. I am fully insured, I am  UKCP and ACPP  registered and all my work in supervised according to professional and ethical requirements. 

Previously, I worked as a designer for different companies while living in Spain, and also in the UK where I have been living for around a decade now. I can offer therapy sessions in both English and Spanish.

 I offer an 30 min intro session free of charge and affordable rate of £30 for an hour session. I practice at the Practice Rooms in Southville, Stokes Croft and Westbury on Trim. Please get in touch for more information.

name: Cost of Living - Community Warm Space-Juice
description:
During bank holidays, opening times may vary so please check the organisation’s website for updates”

Visitors will receive a food box that will last around 3 days plus toiletries if they need them. It is then explained that they can have a box every week for 2 weeks while we work with them to make sure they are linked to the right services.

On the second week we try to find out a little more about their situation. If we feel after 2 weeks that they still require food we are able to extent the time period . All our food in the boxes is ambient and long life but is picked so that meals can be made out of it. As we also have food from Waitrose on a Wednesday and Asda on a Tuesday so people can come along and supplement what they receive daily as this is available to the whole community.

name: Cost of Living - Community Warm Space: Caedmon Complex
description:
Opens September 2024

Facilities: Free tea and coffee, Mental health support, Free wi-fi, Free charging points for phone and other devices, wellbeing support and Activities such as cooking and budgeting courses.

Our building has been here for many years and the welcome space will be a welcomed addition to what we already offer to the local community. The building itself has disabled access ,disabled toilets and parking onsite. There will be a member of staff available to welcome people and answer any questions that they may have .We have a room available so people can speak privately to a member of staff or just need some time by themselves.               

The community welcome space will bring people together in the community and help promote a sense of community .It also is going to help those people who feel socially isolated especially over the winter months to meet new people and make new friends.

description:
During bank holidays, opening times may vary so please check the organisation’s website for updates

Families can expect a warm welcome from school staff and then the opportunity to use the facility in confidence to ensure that they are able to provide for their family. We have been working with the local foodbank we are currently able to offer a small pantry of staple goods. We are also making up a number of food parcels that contain cupboard essentials and a few seasonal products that are available to our most vulnerable visitors when there are prolonged periods of school closure, for example over half and end of terms. These are primarily to ensure families have the provisions for any children who would normally receive a hot meal at school to continue to do so when school is closed.

Open Mon-Fri 8.30am-3.30pm

organization.name: Warmley Community Centre
organization.description:
We have several rooms that we hire.  As a charity supporting lots of charitable businesses, our prices are competitive.

Our hirers often run community events such as parties and fund raising events.  But sometimes private functions such as a special birthday or an important meeting.  We also have regular hirers providing services to the community.

For more information take a look at ‘Our Groups‘ page.

We run our own events too!  These are open to the community and will be advertised on our Facebook page.  Why not pop along to see whats going on!

We are able to provide kitchen and bar facilities with some of our hires.

name: Cost of Living - Community Welcome Space- The Beacon
description:
A very warm welcome, pay-as-you-can café serving great quality, locally sourced hot & cold food, drinks, cake and snacks.

All donations are anonymous.

Companionship, support & signposting. Separate indoor play area for children. On the first Tuesday of every month, we run a popular pay-as-you-can Eat & Meet 2-course lunch.

Everyone is welcome and there are always several people to chat to and get to know.

Must be pre-booked on our website, by phone or in person. Whilst our indoor play area is open at all times, we run a Bumps, Babies & Tots group every Friday between 10am and 12pm where users can meet other parents and have a safe space for their children to play. We host The Centre for Deaf once a month, new members are very welcome. Please check the latest dates at https://www.facebook.com/CfDHoH

Tuesday 12pm – 2pm 1st Tuesday of every month, Eat & Meet (must be booked in advance). Thursday and Friday 9am - 3pm (food until 2pm). Saturday 9am-2pm (food until 1.30pm).

The Kingswood Kitchen Free Drinks and Companionship for Diners; Pay-as-you-Can Hot Nutritious Meals; Accessibility for House-Bound Residents; Support and Signposting; Friendly Volunteers at the Kitchen; Phone Support with a Personal Touch;

name: Cost of Living - Vassall Centre Hot Desking
description: Bristol Charities are offering free hot desking to anyone working alone in the BS16 postcode area. They are offering a warm space for people to work to help with the cost-of-living crisis.  Hot desking is available on a Tuesday and Friday. Email office@vassallcentre.org.uk to book.

name: Cost of Living - Warm Space - Staple Hill Community Hub
description:
During bank holidays, opening times may vary so please check the organisation’s website for updates

We provide an emergency food parcel service to fill the gap while people are in crises; this can be for various reasons including, have been sanctioned by the DWP, or waiting for a referral to a food bank, or have fallen into arrears and are paying back debts. We provide enough food for a week. A typical parcel consists of tinned and packaged goods, dairy products (including cheese and eggs), tea, coffee, cleaning products, toiletries and we also add a few treats eg biscuits, chocolates and crisps. We try to cater to any dietary requirements whenever possible. We also provide dog and cat food for those with pets.

Open: 

Monday 12:00-16:00     

Tuesday from 10:00-15:00    

Wednesday from 10:00-16:00    

Thursday from 10:00-16:00    

Friday from 10:00- 16:00

name: Cost of Living - Welcoming Space at The Secret Cafe - Cycle Cafe
description:
CYCLE CAFE @ The Secret Cafe in the grounds of St Stephen's Church

  • Monthly meet up for volunteers, participants or people who want to find out more about the services Life Cycle offer to help get you cycling. Everyone welcome, drop in any time, first tea/coffee is on us!
  • Opening Times: 10.30-12pm - Third Thursday of every month - Thursday 19th January 2023.
  • Location: The Secret Café, grounds of St Stephens Church, 21 St Stephen's St, Bristol BS1 1EQ

organization.name: Cost of Living - Life Cycle
organization.description:
Life Cycle UK is a registered charity (1077575) that was founded in 1999 and now works with 9,000+ people a year.

In our age of climate emergency, rising inequality and public health crisis, we believe:

More cycling is vital for better physical, mental and environmental health.
Cycling can be safe, affordable and practical for most short journeys.
With the right support, almost anyone can cycle.

Our Vision
A world with clean air and healthy people where cycling is the chosen mode of transport, for most people, for short daily journeys.

Our Mission
We help more people get cycling, to transform lives and the environment.

What we do
To achieve this, we:

 Offer people access to working bicycles
 Help people gain the skills and confidence to cycle wherever they want, whenever they want
 Offer extra support to anyone who faces barriers to unlock the benefits of cycling
 Strengthen the cycling sector: we train new bike mechanics, cycle instructors and partner with Local Authorities, businesses and other charities looking to boost cycling levels.

name: Cost of living service- Citizens Advice Bristol
description:
Cost of living

Struggling with the cost of living?

Our Cost of Living Advice Assistants are providing face-to-face support in Welcoming Spaces across the city.

If you are struggling with the rising cost of living, Citizens Advice Bristol can give you support and guidance.

We can provide practical guidance around benefits, money, debt and energy. We can also signpost you to specialist legal advice if you need more assistance.

See website for details

name: Cost of Living Services - Welcoming Space at Bannerman Road Children's Centre
description:
· Early Education for children aged 2 – 3 year old
· Family Services
· Community Groups

Advice support
Mental health wellbeing support

Our Ethos and Values

These are the guiding beliefs that characterise our attitudes and aspirations as a centre. All five values are underpinned with a nurturing practice.

AMBITION
We provide opportunities to access new experiences, providing a challenging and playful environment that helps plant the seed to develop ideas. We believe in helping each other, offering support and encouragement to try something new in a safe environment for learning

RESPONSIBILITY
We value our partnerships with families, children, professionals and our community, supporting everyone to be unique and develop a positive sense of their own identity and culture

PERSEVERENCE
We believe the process is more important than the end result. We will all achieve in different ways, life is a journey not a destination. We are sensitive and responsive to individual needs, feelings and interests fostering a can do approach

INDEPENDENCE
We build individuals self-worth and self-esteem through warm consistent relationships. We value children and we value learning in a stimulating, natural environment

RESPECT
Everyone has a voice and a right to be heard. All children their families and staff are valued and respected equally

organization.name: Bristol Somali Resource Centre
organization.description:
The Bristol Somali Resource Centre (BSRC) is community based organisation which supports people who are socially and economically disadvantaged in particular but not limited to people of Somali origin and heritage living and/or working within Bristol.

It is a registered charity set up by group of local volunteers in 2008 to help newly arrived immigrants.
BSRC provides free and impartial information, advice and guidance on range of issues including welfare, housing, immigration, schools and employment.

We aim to get the voice of the Somali community heard in the area, promote community cohesion and reduce the isolation of Somali people.

BSRC has been, and continues to be a key partner for organisations and bodies seeking to establish facts and understanding of the Somali community.

The service is open to all, but has a focus on supporting the Somali community in Bristol.

name: Cost of Living Services - Welcoming Space at Port of Bristol Sports & Community Hub
description:
Services available:

  • signposting to other services
  • community activity
  • hot drinks
  • wifi
  • charging points

From its picturesque and peaceful location, the club, its facilities, staff and volunteers, serve our local village and the North Bristol area. It is a welcoming, recreational space for residents, members and guests to enjoy. At its heart, the ‘PBA’ connects people and communities and has charitable aims, it acts as a hub for all to relax, have some fun, take part in active pursuits and escape the hustle and bustle of City life.

Once a membership club for Port and Council workers, the club is now open each weekday evening and all weekend for anyone to enjoy. Our community hub is also available for bookings in the daytime throughout the week; there are no restrictions to using the facilities or hiring the space although becoming a member and supporting the club comes with benefits.

name: Cost of Living Services - Welcoming Space at Southmead Development Trust
description:
Services include:

  • wifi and charging points
  • hot drinks (cafe open from 8:30am to 2:30pm)

Supporting our Community to Thrive

We are a charity made up of staff, volunteers and residents who work together to release power in our community.  By working alongside residents in North Bristol our expert teams help communities to be strong, vibrant and resourceful through building health, wellbeing, learning, employment and pride of place.

We manage the Greenway Centre and The Ranch (Southmead Adventure Playground), providing inspiring and accessible community spaces for young people, adults, families, community groups, partners and businesses.  They are well-loved local venues and host popular community events throughout the year including the Southmead Festival and community pantomime.

We are proud of our impact and that for every £1 we invest we generate £50 in social value.

St Werburghs Community Centre has been providing a range of services, courses and events for local residents for over 50 years. Set in a beautiful Victorian building, bursting full of character and conveniently close to Bristol City Centre, our modern multi-purpose venue offers affordable rates and accessible spaces for both private and public events.

But we are more than just a venue for hire. Explore, take a tour and find out more about what your local community centre can provide for you. We have a range of family and wellbeing services available, digital inclusion support and a vibrant range of events and classes run throughout the year.

There is something for everyone here at St Werburghs Community Centre.

name: Cost of living- Community Warm Space: Kingsmeadow @ MadeForever
description:
During bank holidays, opening times may vary so please check the organisation’s website for updates

Visitors can expect to receive emergency hot meals in our Community Café. Food parcels are available to residents including both long life items (such as tinned soup, beans, vegetables, tomatoes and pasta sauce, dried pasta and rice, tinned meat and fish, teabags, UHT milk, fruit juice, biscuits and cereal), together with fresh items including fruit, vegetables, herbs, bread and bakery products. Where needed, residents are also provided with emergency clothing and blankets, gas / electricity top-up support, essential hygiene kits, baby care products and household items including furniture.

By visiting the Hub, residents are also made aware of our additional support services. These include emotional support services, a programme of activity providing a safe space for people to express their emotions, fears, and anxieties confidentially and freely, supported by our trained and experienced staff. If appropriate, they are signposted to our Health and Wellbeing Activity Groups. They can also be signposted towards other services that operate out of the building. The Hub is also a designated Warm Space.


Opening times Monday-Friday 10-4pm

organization.name: Kensington Baptist Church
organization.description:
We are a large diverse church made up of people from all kinds of backgrounds and nationalities.

Join us on Sunday mornings in our building, or via our live stream, and stay for a meal together every other week. We also meet for an evening service, and in smaller groups throughout the week.

On Sunday, our service officially starts at 11:00 and includes readings from the Bible, songs, prayers, a children’s talk, a sermon and children’s groups. Do join us before this for our prayer meeting at 10:00 and refreshments at 10:30. Every other week, after the service, we have a meal together in the church building. See our calendar for more details.

Mid-week small groups are really important to us. These are great opportunities to meet together to study the Bible, pray and care for one another. These meet on Tuesdays and Wednesdays in different home across the city.

During the week there are other opportunities to meet together and reach out to the local neighbourhood and city with the good news about Jesus.

If you’ve got any questions about Kensington or the Christian faith, please let us know by filling out the form below and someone will be in touch.

The café will be open 10am-4.00pm on most Thursdays in June and July, specific days listed below, serving hot drinks and homemade cakes, and from 11am—12.30pm you’ll be able to get hands-on with a free creative activity hosted by some wonderful local artists. Pop in!

Thursdays in July: 7th, 14th, 21st, 28th

name: creativeShift CIC
description: creativeShift CIC creativeShiftCIC is one of the leading organisations in Bristol providing Arts on Referral programmes and creative wellbeing activities, to adults who are experiencing or are vulnerable to, isolation and mental health challenges. Together with our Bristol Arts on Referral Alliance (BARA) partners: Arts and Events Team Bristol City Council, Bristol Public Health, Fresh Arts, Knowle West Healthy Living Centre, Southmead Development Trust and Wellspring Healthy Living Centre, we deliver in areas of under representation, partnering with organisations working locally with marginalised people. Each programme and project is tailored to the particular community, ensuring we engage the most hard to reach people. creativeShift aims to: Improve wellbeing through involvement in arts activities Focus on those who are experiencing or vulnerable to isolation and mental health challenges Bring together different communities through the arts; using arts to create bridges between people, their communities and culture Develop collaborations with relevant organisations in response to need Continue to advance the practice of arts for wellbeing Our programmes connect individuals more with others and encourage them to take greater notice of the world around them; improve individuals’ wellbeing, self-esteem and confidence. The benefits of our work are that people become more active and engaged; share, give and work as part of a group; provide peer support and learn new skills. Participants are referred to our project by local organisations which work with vulnerable people experiencing a range of mental health challenges and health issues, and who are in need of support. For example: homeless people living in supported housing people recovering from drug and alcohol addiction people with mental illness women affected by domestic violence, post-natal depression and other support issues. adults through the social prescribing remit Our projects offer an opportunity to both individuals and the referring organisations, to further progress an individual’s recovery/progression plan through creative activity and help them to engage with wider society by attending a new venue, meet new people, provide peer support and learn new skills. Typically our programmes offer participants weekly 2 hour group workshops for up to 18 sessions. These relaxed and friendly art sessions are led by an artist with a background in socially engaged practice and experienced in facilitating Arts on Referral groups. Participants are gently introduced to a range of ideas and techniques to help them explore their own creativity and learn new skills at their own pace. No previous arts experience is necessary. Sessions are focused on arts and wellbeing and are different to counselling or therapy. The workshops are based in community hubs and connect with the wider social prescribing network. We currently work in Southmead, St Pauls, Knowle West and Hartcliffe, please visit Home (creativeshift.org.uk)

name: Cruse Bereavement Care
description:
Cruse provides care and support for bereaved children, young people and adults in the UK. 

You will find useful information and advice for bereaved people and those around them including family, friends, employers and service providers.

You will also find information about how you can help our charity as a volunteer, by raising money for our projects and services and helping in other ways.

Phone lines are often busy. If you cannot get through please leave a message with your name and number and they will get back to you as quickly as possible.

If you urgently need to talk to someone outside of office hours please call our national helpline – 0808 808 1677

All services are free. 

Opening hours

  • Monday: 9.30am-5pm
  • Tuesday: 9.30am-8pm
  • Wednesday: 9.30am-8pm
  • Thursday: 9.30am-8pm
  • Friday: 9.30am-5pm
  • Saturday : 10am-2pm
  • Sunday: 10am-2pm

Speak to us via CruseChat

Chat online with expert grief counsellors.

name: Curam
description:
Curam gives clients who want to self-manage choice and control over who provides their care. Our technology allows you to connect with PAs/Care Professionals in minutes. Our Care Professionals come with an average of 10years experience in the sector, qualifications, and certificates.  

Our platform is great for arranging regular care as well as respite care, last minute care for supporting hospital discharge or covering a current PAs annual leave/sickness. Care has been arranged and delivered in as little as 30minutes from sign up to the Care Professional being there to help.

Curam gives PAs/Care Professionals choice and control over who they are working for, and they are also well rewarded for the excellent service they provide, earning 85% of what is charged. Curam has a very thorough vetting process for the approval of PAs/Care Professionals to operate on the platform. All invoicing and payments are made via the platform and all shifts are insured.

Curam is working with direct payment recipients in 100 different local authority areas, as well as self-funded clients and those in receipt of NHS funding. Hourly, overnight, short notice and live-in care are available on Curam. Service users can search using the filter options, allowing you to find a PA/Care Professional with the specific expertise you require, for example, Dementia experience or someone who is trained and competent in Epilepsy management.  

If you’d like find a Care Professional near you just head to our website or download our app. You can browse their profiles or post your care requirements completely free of charge.

name: Deafblind UK
description:
Deafblind UK is a national charity supporting people with sight and hearing loss to live the lives they want. 

We help people to live with deafblindness by making connections, building their confidence and independence. 

Living with combined sight and hearing loss can be frightening. Our team of experts is here every step of the way to reassure, advise or just to be someone to turn to if there is no one else.

Our services include: 

  • Helpline: 0800 132 320 Call us on 0800 132320 or text us 07903572885
    Monday – Thursday 8.30am – 5.00pm and Fridays 8.30am – 4.00pm
  • Wellbeing and emotional support
  • Care and support
  • Supported living
  • Befriending
  • Social groups
  • Technology
  • Open Hand magazine
  • Holidays
  • Empowering support

organization.name: Deafblind UK
organization.description:
Deafblind UK exists because too many people are living with deafblindness and are not getting the help they need. We show people that there can be a life beyond deafblindness.
Whether you need some support to get back on your feet after a diagnosis, a helping hand to help you do the things you love, someone to turn to when you’re feeling low or some information, advice and guidance, we’re here to help.
Losing your sight and hearing can be frightening. Our team of experts is here every step of the way to show you life beyond sight and hearing loss.

name: Decluttering Services
description:
Mrs ClutterBug is here to deliver a service that helps you to maximise space and give every item in your home its own place. I am non-judgemental and understand that hoarding behaviour can be associated with mental health struggles, so you will get ongoing support to change habits of a lifetime. I am able to assist with all areas of the home, focussing on long-term storage solutions and general decluttering. I can also support by taking items to the charity shop/recycling centre where mobility is an issue. Examples of the services I offer:
Full Kitchen/pantry declutter and organise
Full bedroom closet/wardrobe/ drawers
Storage cupboards
Nursery-Kids full bedroom declutter and organisation including toys and clothes
Bookcases-shelves organisation
Lifestyle coaching and mentoring
Cleaning routines and decluttering plans
Garage-garden sheds declutter and organise
Online support
Get in touch today to see how I can help you change your life!

description:
Alive has a community allotment in North Bristol where we offer supported gardening and socialising sessions for people living with dementia and their carers.

The allotment is on Charlton Road Allotments, Brentry, BS10 6JZ.

organization.name: Alive Activities
organization.description:
Alive is one of the leading practitioners in the UK of meaningful activity for older people in care. We provide fun and dynamic activity sessions to encourage creativity, celebrate life stories and get the circulation going.

We’re different to other activity providers because we enable older people to shape the content and direction of Alive sessions, which include the use of new technology, guided reminiscence, creative, energising and physical activities. We entertain but we’re more than entertainers. We engage older people in meaningful ways using a variety of tools and techniques tried and tested over the last 10 years.

name: Dental Fear Central
description:
Are you filled with a feeling of dread or terror at the thought of visiting a dentist? 

Dental Fear Central is the web’s biggest dental phobia resource. We provide lots of information on how to tackle a fear or phobia of the dentist, as well as support forum. Run by volunteers, we provide both peer support and advice from qualified health professionals.

We also provide information for dentists and psychologists on helping their anxious or phobic patients, and on providing trauma-informed care.

name: Develing Deeper Menopause Course
description:
This 6 weeks course is a chance to meet other women experiencing the same symptoms as yourself. It will give you an opportunity to share with each other how you're dealing with the changes that are happening to you and how you are all managing them. 

I will walk you through what is happening to your body and go through why the changes in your hormones make you feeling the way you are. Once you have an understanding of what is happening with your hormones and metabolism we can then discuss a plan of action and look at some lifestyle changes you can make to take back control of your mind and body!

We will support each other as a group to feel strong enough to tackle any changes to our sleep patterns, exercise, eating, stress and many more ways we can look to improve our symptoms and how we feel. Once you understand that your body is really going through a dramatic change at a chemical level and therefore you need to change your habits to accommodate these fundamental changes then you can move into your post menopause years much more knowledgable and with a healthier approach to life!

This longer course will dive deeper each week into the chemical changes that effect our minds and bodies. It's a great follow on from the intro workshop. Covering 6 main areas of lifestyles that we can change to cope with our new menopause bodies.

Module 1 - Drinking water during menopause - why is this so essential?

Module 2 - Eating for your menopause body - a new approach to nutrition

Module 3 - `Effects of stress and metabolism during menopause - stress creates havoc to menopausal women

Module 4 - New approach to exercise for menopause bodies - a new approach to exercise

Module 5 - Menopause and insomnia - Why ? - sleep deprivation has a profound affect on our minds and bodies

Module 6 - A natural approach to menopause - talking about supplements, vitamins and minerals

The longer course will dive deeper each week into the chemical changes that effect our minds and bodies. It is ideal to follow on from the 1.5 hrs workshop.

If your are interested in the longer course email me on info@kb-fitnessforlife.com.

name: Developing Health & Independence (DHI)
description:
Developing Health & Independence is a local charity that was set up in 1999 to help people out of the cycle of homelessness, social isolation and drug or alcohol abuse.

One of our strengths is being able to respond to our clients’ needs by offering a tailored programme from a range of practical and emotional support services.

We do not provide Out of Hours or emergency support. If you need help in an emergency or outside of our working hours (9am-5pm Monday to Friday), visit our Out of hours help page.

We offer a range of services in Bath & North East Somerset, Bristol, Wiltshire, South Gloucestershire and Somerset: 


​​​​​​​Adult drug & alcohol treatment

Young people's drug & alcohol services

Housing provision

Housing advice and support

Families & carers services

Social Prescribing

organization.name: Developing Health & Independence
organization.description: We run innovative services to help disadvantaged people and those living on the margins of society turn their lives around. For example: supported housing, drug treatment and social prescribing.

name: Dhek Bhal
description:
Respite breaks
Day care
Self help
Advocacy activities

for the South Asian Community in Bristol & South Gloucestershire


Dhek Bhal believes that everyone in the South Asian Community:

  • has rights and responsibilities and is entitled to dignity and respect.
  • has the right to quality services to meet individual needs.
  • has the right to opportunities which will promote individual development.
  • has the right to information.
  • has the right to make choices.
  • should be able to contribute to the development of services directly or through a representative, family member or advocate.

Dhek Bhal's Aims and Objectives

These are to provide a range of quality services including :

  • Respite services for Carers of South Asian elders (disabled and able bodied) through a Sitting Service.
  • A Daycentre service for frail and disabled elderly women and men.
  • An Outreach Support Scheme for housebound and frail disabled elders, and their Carers.
  • A Carer Support Group for both male and female Carers to address their social, health, educational and training needs.
  • Work to develop new projects and services, either as an organisation or in partnership with others.
  • Manage our operations including fundraising and finance in the most effective manner.

Dhek Bhal organise and fund many good causes and projects, that combine to make the area a better place to be. Please choose one of the projects below for more information.

  • Womens Day Centre Project
  • Men's Centre
  • Carers' Project
  • Sitting Service

name: Diabetes UK - South West
description:
Welcome to Diabetes UK South West

Working to raise awareness, improve care and provide help, support and information for people with diabetes and their families in the South West region.


Contact us

Meet the South West team and find out about what we do

Support

There are many ways in which we can help people with diabetes in the South West, such as our Local Groups who offer support at public meetings.

Volunteering

Get involved in our work to raise awareness, fundraise, campaign and provide help and information for people with diabetes in the South West

Regional news

Find out the latest news happening here in the South West


Whether you are looking to join one of our local groups and have a chat over a cup of tea, read printed leaflets with the latest information or phone our helpline, there are many ways in which we can support you with your diabetes.

We support people across the South West who are affected by diabetes, whether you or someone you know has been recently diagnosed, or if you have been living with type 1 or type 2 diabetes for a long time, or if you are a healthcare professional.

Here are some of the ways that we can help:

Our local groups

We have different types of groups across our region run by our volunteers:

Adult groups

Our adult groups help support people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Many groups run meetings where you can find out the latest information in a social and friendly environment. Some groups also have a Facebook page where you join an online community to chat and share experiences with others.

Go to our Listing of Local Groups page to find your nearest one.

You can also volunteer with our local groups and get involved with a range of activities from fundraising to organising events.

Children and families groups

Being diagnosed and living with diabetes at an early age can feel daunting and confusing. Our children and families groups provide face to face support, organising events where parents and children meet up, have fun and find out the latest information.

Go to our Listing of Local Groups page to find your nearest one.

You can also volunteer with our local children's and families' groups. For more information, please phone or email our South West team at south.west@diabetes.org.uk.

Information

As well as lots of great information on our guide to diabetes we have a range of printed materials about living with diabetes that you may find useful. If you want us to send these out to you then please email or phone the South West team.

Talk to someone

You can contact our helpline service on 0345 123 2399 for advice and support. We have advisors with counselling skills and an extensive knowledge of diabetes. It’s the cost of a local call and the service is available between 9am and 7pm on Monday to Friday.

Contact the South West Office

Phone: 01823 448 260

Email: south.west@diabetes.org.uk

name: Dimensions
description:
In 1976, armed with a single phone in a rented office, Dimensions began supporting people with learning disabilities, autism and complex needs out of institutions, helping them lead ordinary lives in their local communities.

Forty years on, our work is fundamentally unchanged: we support people with learning disabilities and autistic people to have a louder voice, choice and control in their lives. Our 7000 colleagues deliver ambitious, effective, personalised support often with those whose previous support has not been successful.

Working alongside our colleagues are family members and many of the people we support. They could be quality checkers, interviewers or members of our Council. Their voices and experiences inform the research we use to deliver improved outcomes. Together, we continue to prove that life really can get better.

Through our person-centred approach we support:

    • People with profound and multiple learning disabilities
    • People with complex autism
    • People needing full time support, and those needing a little less
    • People with complex health needs
    • People whose behaviour may challenge those around them
    • People in assessment and treatment units
    • Young adults leaving school and college
    • People with forensic support needs
    • People looking for a place to live
    • People and families needing a break
    • People seeking employment

name: Dimensions – Autism friendly environments nationwide
description:
Looking for autism friendly things to do? Dimensions UK work with cinemas, libraries, museums and Belong by GAME Arenas. Each venue’s autism friendly training is tailored to their environment and guests. Adjustments include reduced sensory stimulation, increased signage and autism training for staff. Our training is developed with autism and industry experts, so it works for both our guests and the venues.

Autism friendly screenings are held at over 300 cinemas nationwide: ODEON, Cineworld, Vue, Showcase, Picturehouse, Everyman, Light and some independent cinemas. The screenings take place regularly and have adjustments to make the cinema experience more enjoyable for people with autism or sensory sensitivity. To find out more about Autism Friendly screenings you can visit the Dimensions website or the Dimensions Facebook page, or your local cinema.

name: Disability Advice, Information and Resources
description:
Disability Rights UK campaign in parliament on behalf of all disabled people in areas including: 

  •  Increasing opportunities in education and employment.
  • Changing attitudes to disability.
  • Independent living – getting a life.

We sell the RADAR accessible toilet key and the leading guide to benefits and rights – The Disability Rights Handbook.  These can be purchased from our online Shop.

To help disabled people understand the benefits system we have produced a number of factsheets that can be downloaded for free from our website.

www.disabilityrightsuk.org

1. Independent living: getting a life

  • Advice and information 
  • Get Yourself Active project
  • Disability Rights Handbook
  • Radar Keys
  • Training on disability rights and welfare benefits 

2. Career opportunities: getting work, education and skills

  • Advice and information 
  • Employer services
  • Good practice in supporting disabled learners toolkit
  • Leadership Academy Programme
  • Training and consultancy

3. Influencing public attitudes and behaviours: seeking a sea change in perceptions of disability and tackling hostility, bullying and hate crime

  • Stopping disability hate crime​​​​​​​

Disability Rights UK is the UK’s leading organisation led by, run by, and working for Disabled people.

We work with Disabled People’s Organisations and Government across the UK to influence regional and national change for better rights, benefits, quality of life and economic opportunities for Disabled people.

Quality Domestic Cleaning in Bristol

At Splashernet, we have the Bristol domestic cleaners that you have been waiting for so long!

Our exceptional Bristol domestic cleaning service can be booked Monday to Sunday and our professional cleaners can start cleaning on the same day from only £12p/h, with no commitments, and no hidden fees.

name: Driving and Mobility Centre, West of England
description:
Driving and Mobility Centre, West of England
This organisation offers assessments and information to help disabled or older people safely maintain their mobility and independence. The following services are available, conducted by highly trained Driving Advisers and Occupational Therapists:
INDIVIDUAL DRIVING AND ADAPTATION ASSESSMENTS
The aim of these assessments is to keep people independently mobile and help them achieve safe driving. There is a selection of adapted cars at the centre, including a Wheelchair Accessible Vehicle (WAV).
PASSENGER ASSESSMENTS
These assessments provide training and advice on getting in and out of a car more comfortably, and also for loading and stowing of mobility equipment including the use of an EQUIPMENT HOIST.
SCOOTER ASSESSMENTS
Through professional review of personal requirements these free assessments provide the information you need in order to decide on a genuinely appropriate scooter.
INFORMATION
Free advice and information is available on a wide range of driving and mobility issues.
DO PLEASE CALL US to find out more and how to make an appointment. Every effort is made to answer telephone calls personally, but at times this is not always possible and a message left on the answer phone will be dealt with as soon as possible.
You can also visit our web site, shown above.

Fees:
£55 if referred by a health professional
£95 self referral (we still need medical information)
Free to client if referred by DVLA or Motability.
£150 Professional referral

name: Driving Miss Daisy
description:
Our passion is to empower people to get out and about, socialise and enjoy all that life has to offer. We do this through a combination of companionship and assisted transportation.

Our companion drivers are friendly, compassionate, and will be on hand to help you or your loved ones live life to the full.

Our visits may include:

  • Medical appointments with the option of a companion to feedback to family
  • Accompanied shopping trips
  • Going for walks or meeting up with friends
  • Light domestic duties
  • Provide company at home by reading, listening to music, playing board or card games

Catering for special needs, learning or physical disabilities, health or medical issues, or simply those who need a little extra compassion and time to do what they want at their own pace.

name: EACH - Educational Action Challenging Homophobia
description:
What to do if you are the target of homophobic, biphobic or transphobic bullying 

EACH provides a free and confidential, homophobic, biphobic or transphobic bullying reporting service for children and young people up to 18 years of age. If you have been a target of this bullying you can call our freephone Helpline on 0808 1000 143 (Monday to Friday, 9:00am – 4:30pm) or scroll this section to the bottom and use our online self-reporting form to receive the same support.

Our training and consultancy strives to reduce discrimination, harassment or bullying experienced by way of gender identity or sexual orientation. We aspire to affirm confidence in all service-users: inspiring trust and empowering individuals or organisations to make sensible choices informed by legislation and mutually agreed decisions.

Our services include:

  • Delivering Speaker led interactive training and consultancy to help national and regional agencies better understand legislation regarding gender identity or sexual orientation matters to effect change at strategic and practical levels
  • Assisting employers to develop best practice in supporting lesbian, gay, bisexual or trans employees and voluntary workers
  • Inspiring schools, academies, colleges and universities to implement policy and procedural change concerning sexual orientation and gender identity issues through Department for Education and PSHE Association endorsed resources, training and consultancy: working with pupils, students, staff and governors 
  • Integrating thirty-four years’ professional experience to inform books and Government commissioned national guidance and training including ‘Safe to Learn’ (DCSF), ‘Inspiring Equality in Education’ and ‘Learn Equality Live Equal’ (DfE), the ‘Reach Teaching Resource’ (National Lottery), the JKP books, “That’s So Gay! Challenging Homophobic Bullying” (2015), “How To Stop Homophobic & Biphobic Bullying: A Practical Whole School Approach” (2020) the  co-development of  the Welsh Government’s statutory Schools’ Anti-Bullying Guidance ‘Rights, Respect, Equality’ .

name: Early Years Drop-in SEND Support
description:
If you are concerned about your child’s early development or need help navigating your child’s disability, you can drop in to our Early Years SEND support session

These relaxed and friendly support sessions offer a safe space where your voice and experiences will be heard. Our Peer Support Team can:
•    Share ideas and effective strategies to help you become more confident in identifying and supporting your child’s needs
•    Signpost you to services that may be beneficial to your family 
•    Offer useful information around key transitions such as starting school
•    Provide a listening ear over a cuppa 

These weekly drop-in support sessions are also a great opportunity to connect with others in similar situations and share information and experiences. There will be toys available for your child to play with, but please can we remind you that you are responsible for supervising your own children at all times.

Open every Wednesday during term time

A busy hub open seven days a week offering affordable meeting and office spaces with a café, nursery and community radio station.

The centre is at the heart of our community providing a sustainable, secure, welcoming, culturally diverse and accessible space that is valued and supported by the people of East Bristol.

We are committed to providing affordable and flexible space for community use. Easton Community Centre has a great selection of rooms and meeting spaces. Each with its own unique feel, they are perfect for holding training courses, workshops, meetings, classes or parties.

Facilities: 

  • Free Wifi

  • Photocopying services

  • Printing and scanning services

  • Community table tennis bats (for the community tables in Owen Square Park)

  • Space for advertising local events and businesses

  • Accessible toilets and baby change facilities for all the community

description:
Here at Easton Leisure Centre, we pride ourselves on the breadth of activities we offer to help keep you and your family happy, healthy and, above all, active. Our state-of-the-art gym is packed with the latest kit, while our swimming pool is ideal for those wanting to learn, get fit or just have fun on our water slide. We also offer a huge programme of instructor-led group fitness classes, while our squash courts are popular too.

You can also enjoy badminton and five-a-side football in our sports hall.

Due to the nature of restrictions easing we encourage you to view the website for the most up to date information on facilities and opening hours. 

Easton Leisure Centre | Gym, Swim & Fitness Classes | Everyone Active

0117 955 8840 (general) and 0117 903 8000 (gym)

eastoninfo@everyoneactive.com

organization.name: Everyone Active
organization.description:
Part of Sports and Leisure Management Ltd, Everyone Active is the longest-established leisure contractor in the UK, having been founded in 1987.

"We are called Everyone Active for a reason: we have made it our mission to encourage everyone we come into contact with to participate in at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity, either in one of our centres or via online training, five times per week. To help us achieve this mission, we manage over 200 leisure and cultural centres across the UK in partnership with more than 60 different local authorities. We are passionate about being active and staying healthy, and we want our members to be too. Whether it is state-of-the art gym equipment, excellent sports facilities, Swim England-accredited swimming programmes or fun activities for children, our centres aim to offer something for the entire community to enjoy." 

Centre contact details available on the website

Also a provider for St Paul's Community Sports Academy.

name: Elijah’s Hope CIC
description: Elijah’s Hope is a Community Interest Company (CIC) aimed at bringing together families affected by the rare disease, Apert Syndrome. Approximately one in 65,000 babies is born with Apert Syndrome, which is a genetic disorder characterised by the premature fusion of certain skull bones. This early fusion prevents the skull from growing normally and affects the shape of the head and face. In addition, people with Apert Syndrome tend to experience syndactyly, where a number of fingers and toes are fused together.

name: Employment Support
description:
One Front Door is here to help you navigate the employment services across Bristol. We can help you find employment, training and advice. We can work with you to help you develop your skills, gain experience and find the job that is right for you.

If you have specialist needs we can help you access specialist support. For example, those who are self employed or who wish to start their own business, or those with learning difficulties or disabilities.

We can help you to:

enhance your skills and abilities through training and work experience

build your knowledge of the job market

find out about vacancies in Bristol

build your confidence and assertiveness and a create positive self-image.

WHO CAN USE THIS SERVICE?

The service is open to anyone living in the Bristol area (anyone whose local authority is Bristol City Council).

HOW CAN I SIGN UP?

To sign up simply fill out the contact form below and one of our Career Progression Coaches will be in touch.

Our service is free and is available to everyone in the city of Bristol

name: Energise Recovery Programme
description:
Energise Health delivers group-based, online facilitated courses in which participants are coached how to optimise their health & wellbeing by integrating simple, scientifically based strategies into their daily lives. The courses are holistic and cover a wide range of strategies to support participants’ physical and mental health. These include mindfulness, belly breathing, tai chi, relaxation and energy management techniques, healthy eating and many more.

Energise Recovery and Energise Recovery 4Life are our 6-week courses designed for people at varying stages following injury or diagnosis of a long-term health condition. They provide participants with the knowledge, skills and confidence to proactively manage their health condition and can improve clinical outcomes and reduce the need for medical input.

organization.name: Energise Health
organization.description:
Energise Recovery is a series of educational Recovery Facilitation Programmes (RFP) which are taught online by highly skilled Facilitators. 

Designed for people at varying stages following injury or diagnosis of long-term health conditions, Energise Recovery and Energise Recovery 4Life provide a strong foundation for recovery and condition self-management by:

Educating Participants about typical body-mind responses, including pain, stress, anxiety, depression, poor sleep, reduced activity and energy levels 

Supporting Participants to develop a personalised toolkit of practical, evidence-based strategies to manage these responses

Teaching Participants how to integrate these strategies into their daily lives.

We are a United Nations accredited ‘A status’ National Human Rights Institution (NHRI). Their role is to make the country a fairer place by enforcing and upholding the laws that safeguard everyone’s right to fairness, dignity and respect.

name: Fairburn - Respite Care at Milestones Trust
description:
Located in the popular Little Stoke area of South Gloucestershire, our Fairburn service offers people with a learning disability the chance to enjoy a short break away from home while receiving the high level of care that Milestones is renowned for. With a staff team focused on delivering a positive and person-centred experience for everyone staying at the service, it’s no surprise that people who come to stay once end up becoming repeat visitors.

At Fairburn, we work hard to offer people a stimulating and supportive short break that allows the continuity of everyday life to be maintained. We work in partnership with the people we support and their families to plan support that encourages development of daily living skills and offers a taste of independent living – while leaving plenty of time for activities and fun!

Importantly, our short breaks allow parents and carers to take time off from their caring role, comfortable in the knowledge that their loved one is in good hands, and with the reassurance that an update need only be a phone call – or even a quick visit - away.

name: Family Carer Support Service (FCSS)
description:
Hft’s Family Carer Support Service (FCSS) is a free information and support service for family carers with an autistic relative or a relative with a learning disability. To avail of our service, their relative must be aged 16 years or older and living in England.

How can the Family Carer Support Service help you?

We can help in the following ways:

  • Ongoing one-to-one support via telephone and email
  • Email and letter writing
  • Resources designed to simplify complicated topics
  • Bespoke workshops about subjects affecting family carers and their relative
  • Information and guidance with common topics

Common topics include:

  • Adult social care
  • Carers’ rights
  • Personal budgets, direct payments and care packages
  • Financial contributions and disability related expenditure
  • Transition from children’s to adult services
  • The Mental Capacity Act
  • Lasting Power of Attorney, Deputyship, Appointeeship
  • Benefits
  • Planning for the future

If you are experiencing problems with any of the above, feel free to get in touch and we’ll see if we can help. Take a look at the ways you can Contact Us.

Our Freephone line (0808 801 0448) is available between 9.30am – 4.00pm, Monday – Thursday.

Please leave a voicemail if we don’t pick up, or send an email to familycarersupport@hft.org.uk. We aim to get back to you within seven to ten working days.

organization.name: Hft
organization.description:
Hft is one of the largest and longest-established charities supporting people with learning disabilities. 

We are able to invest our knowledge in our staff. We help them to develop the specialist skills and expertise needed to provide the kind of support we believe in. And we try to make sure they always have the time it takes to build trusted, caring relationships with the people and families they support.

Our services range from residential care and day opportunities to supported living/domiciliary care at home – from a few hours a week to 24 hours a day. We provide support that means people with learning disabilities can experience life to the full – from enjoyment, satisfaction and improved health to finding meaningful relationships or paid employment. Our commitment goes beyond being just a high quality support provider.

name: Farm Tots
description: Come and help look after the animals. For parents/carers and under 5's, have fun outdoors with your children with a relaxed, friendly group. Farm Tots is drop-in so you do not need to book, and runs all year round. Please call or look at our Facebook page to check whether is running if weather is bad.
