name: Telecare Services - South Glos
description:
Telecare Services - South Glos

The Telecare Service (formerly Piper Alarms/ Piper Lifeline) is a means of communication in an emergency situation. People can obtain reassurance night and day when they are feeling particularly anxious or in need of help. This service is invaluable to those with mobility and health problems. It enables people to to continue living at home independently.  The system can be installed using an existing phone line.  If there is no phone line we can provide a unit which uses mobile networks.  A lightweight pendant or wrist button is provided which allows the wearer to call for assistance from anywhere in the home.  The system is linked to a monitoring centre which is staffed 24/7 by a team of professionals. The Council’s own Responder Service can attend in some circumstances if there are no relatives or other contacts available.  Anyone can apply for the Service; there is no need for a Social Care assessment.

Wireless sensors can also be linked to the lifeline system and these will trigger an automatic alert if there is a problem in the home.   

Examples additional sensors:

Smoke alarm - the Control Centre will contact the Fire Service immediately if there is smoke in the property. 

Fall detector – this device detects sudden impact and after 20 seconds will activate an alert to the monitoring centre.  

Temperature extreme sensor – triggers an alert if the house becomes too hot or cold.

Property exit sensor – placed on a front or back door, this checks for people leaving a building at unusual times of the day or night.

Bed sensors - to alert if the person has left the bed for longer than expected

 Fees: Please enquire for details as cost depends on level of service.

description: We are an independent, non-governmental organisation which works on tackling anti-Muslim hatred and therefore our work is not influenced or wholly shaped by Government. However, we work with Central Government to raise the issues of anti-Muslim hatred at a policy level and our work helps to shape and inform policy makers, whilst ensuring that an insight is brought into this area of work through the systematic recording and reporting of anti-Muslim hate incidents and crimes.

description:
Nationally there are five types of services, each designed to help in different ways: Information and advice Answer questions about HIV and sexual health. Do you want to know what services are available and where? Call THT Direct and if they can't answer your questions there and then, they'll know someone who can. Counselling and group support All service centres provide one-to-one or couples counselling sessions up for up to 12 weeks.

They also run a variety of group support sessions to suit individual needs. Managing your own health They run various services for people with HIV or sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including treatment advice and courses for those who have recently had their test results. Testing for HIV and other sexually transmitted infections They offer walk-in HIV and STI testing services in community settings around England and Wales. Services are open in the evenings and you'll get your results in an hour.

name: The Advocacy People
description:
The Advocacy People are an independent charity who provide free and confidential advocacy support.

We all know how hard it can be when we don’t feel listened to, when what’s important to us isn’t taken seriously by others, or we just don’t have the words to say what we really feel or want. It can be even more difficult when decisions are being made about our health and social welfare.

The Advocacy People and we can help support people in Bristol with

NHS Complaints Advocacy   IHCA - Supporting you if you have not had the service you expected from a service provided or paid for by the NHS.

Social Care Complaints Advocacy 

Supporting you if you wish to make a complaint about local authority social care services. These are some of the things that you might want to complain about:

  • The attitude or behaviour of staff

  • A care plan, an assessment or review

  • Decisions that you do not agree with

They will take time to understand your situation, explore the options and help you decide what you want to do and how you want to do it. They can give you as much or as little support as you want to put your views across.

organization.name: The Advocacy People
organization.description:
The Advocacy People believe in a society where; people feel in control of their lives and are confident to speak up and people who can’t speak up for themselves have someone in their corner to speak for them.

It is our mission to:  help anybody that needs independent support to speak up, deliver quality and innovation in advocacy through our practice and improve people’s lives individually and collectively through putting their case to policymakers.

name: The Anchor Society
description:
The Anchor Society was established in 1769 and for over 250 years has been committed to supporting vulnerable, older people in the Bristol and neighbouring areas.

Our core criteria are that individuals are aged 55 and over, living in the post code areas BS, BA or GL.

Grants - We provide emergency one-off grants to people who are in genuine immediate need, to enable them to remain independently in their own homes for as long as possible.  The grants are generally for home repairs and adaptations, boiler repairs and replacements, mobility aids, carpets and essential home furnishings.  We usually only accept grant requests from known referrers.  Details of our grant giving policy can be found at :

https://www.anchorsociety.co.uk/grants/

Housing Projects - We have developed eight purpose-built retirement homes in the Lawrence Weston area and aim to build more in the region.

Other Support - The Anchor Society actively promotes working in partnership with other local organisations to provide services for older people and activities to combat isolation and loneliness.  Examples of those we have worked with include BOPFA (Bristol Older People's Funding Alliance), Bristol Beacon, Alive, Age UK Bristol, LinkAge, BiTC (Bristol in The Community) and AAB (Active Ageing Bristol).

name: The Bridge SARC
description:
The Bridge is a Sexual Assault Referral Centre (SARC). We offer medical care, emotional and psychological support, and practical help to anyone who has been raped or sexually assaulted.

Our specialist team will be here for you if you are:

  • An adult or child, living in Bristol, South Gloucestershire, North Somerset, Bath & North East Somerset or Somerset.
  • A child, living in Gloucestershire, Wiltshire or Swindon.

We also offer information and support to friends and family if someone you care about has been affected by rape or serious sexual assault.

Call us for free and confidential advice on 0117 342 6999. We’re here 24/7, 365 days a year.

name: The British Red Cross
description:
The British Red Cross has delivered health and social care services since the NHS was established. We work with commissioners to provide valuable time-limited support to vulnerable people across the UK.

The Red Cross offers person-centred support for adults of all ages. The combination of services we provide can be tailored to meet specific commissioner and health community needs.

We have local teams of highly committed staff and volunteers. They offer quality services that are delivered within our Quality Standards Frameworks to ensure we are supporting people in the best way possible

The services we provide

To help people remain independent or to provide practical and emotional support to people in need, we provide the following services: You can find further details of how to access each service here: https://www.redcross.org.uk/get-help

  • Emotional support
  • Mobility aids services
  • Refugee services
  • Help at home
  • Financial support
  • Help to find missing family

Helping people home from hospital

We help patients get home safely, quickly and effectively through our assisted discharge services. For the first 72 hours after leaving hospital, we make sure people have everything they need at home. If they need more support, we provide personalised help for the next six to twelve weeks.

Reconnecting people with their community

Chronic loneliness and isolation can have a serious impact on health and wellbeing. Our research has shown that before the coronavirus pandemic, one in four people in the UK often or always felt lonely.  Since lockdown, 41 per cent of UK adults report feeling lonelier. Loneliness can be as bad for you as smoking 15 cigarettes a day and is likely to increase your risk of death by 29 per cent.

The British Red Cross recognise we have a role to play in tackling this. We work with local authorities and other organisations to develop and deliver loneliness services alongside other health and wellbeing services such as our support at home services.

Through strong corporate partnership with the likes of Land Rover, we provide staff and volunteers with the resources they need to reach people some of the most isolated rural and remote communities across the UK. This gives people the practical help and emotional support they need before, during and after a crisis.

Find your local support at home service

If you would like help at home, we usually need a referral from your GP or another professional. To find out more or get help with loneliness, contact our team in your area.

01235 552 665

ilcrsouthciadmin@redcross.org.uk

Supporting patients in A&E

In more than 20 A&E departments across the UK, we partner with hospitals to provide practical and emotional support to patients and families. Focusing on issues outside of medical needs, we also help people get home when they don’t need a hospital bed or treatment.

Supporting the ambulance services

We provide ambulance services under contract, primarily with the NHS. We offer services at three levels:

  • patient transport
  • urgent patient transport
  • blue light emergency response. 

We also provide ambulance services under a Royal Charter during surges in demand, predicted periods of high activity or adverse weather events. 

Working closely with commissioners, we help reduce trips to A&E departments and provide supported-discharge services. 

Hiring and loaning wheelchairs and commodes

We hire and loan wheelchairs and commodes to people who need them for a limited time to live independently. This can be part of a stand-alone service or an integrated package.

As the biggest lender of wheelchairs in the UK, we can offer commissioners a contracted-out community equipment service.

Transport for healthcare visits

We provide transport as part of an integrated offer or as a stand-alone service for people who need it due to illness, disability or injury. Our support helps people reach medical and other essential care appointments, and we can use specially adapted vehicles when necessary.

Providing first aid education

If injured people received basic first aid before emergency services arrive, up to 59 per cent of pre-hospital deaths could be prevented. These are the findings from our research and the reason we teach first aid to adults and young people. We also focus on training people who are at a higher risk of experiencing a first aid emergency.

We help anyone, anywhere in the UK and around the world, get the support they need if crisis strikes.
From hiring a wheelchair or dealing with loneliness, to adjusting to life in a new country - we’re there when you need us.

name: The Diversity Trust (& the LGBT network)
description:
The Diversity Trust CIC is a Community Interest Company, established in 2012, in the UK. Our mission is to ‘influence social change to create a fairer and safer society’. The Diversity Trust has undertaken large scale auditing, consultancy projects, research, training and strategic projects across the corporate, public, private, voluntary, community and social enterprise sectors across the UK, as well as internationally. We are specialists in equality, diversity, equity and inclusion.

As an equalities-led organisation, our Leadership and Governance; our staff, volunteers and consultants are all members of a wide range of protected characteristic groups including: Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic Communities, Refugee and Asylum Seekers, LGBTQ+ people, Disabled People, Neurodivergent People and Gender Diverse People and Communities. 

The Diversity Trust supports all minoritised and marginalised communities, in our society, and is especially supportive of the Black Lives Matter, Trans Lives Matter, Refugee Rights and Women’s Rights Movements, thinking and acting intersectionally. We use our voice, and our platforms, to amplify the voices of minoritised and marginalised people and communities. Our broad network of staff, volunteers and consultants brings rich, lived experience critical to helping us and our clients understand the issues of bias and how it helps create structures of institutional and systemic discrimination e.g., ageism, ableism, racism and sexism – across society and within institutions and organisations. 

Our clients include individuals, businesses, and organisations across the corporate, public, and social purpose sectors. We have a wealth of knowledge and experience in policy development, project management, research, evaluation, and training. We are able to advise our client, and partner organisations, on employment and management, as well as service design, development and delivery.

name: The Family Centre (Deaf Children)
description:
The family centre provides support to all deaf families in the regions, enabling a social network for families and a peer group for the children and enabling access to local leisure facilities.

As long as you have a deaf child or parent in your family you can use our service.  Some activities are limited by age range, or have other criteria but these will be clearly shown on the activity details.

We can provide information and advice on deaf issues, run workshops and training, provide social support and improve access to recreational facilities and improve the opportunities available to deaf families. We will also work with other agencies to assist in any aspect of family life!

We run a variety of family activities and kids activities each year, including BSL lessons and a BSL choir and coffee mornings.  We enable peer groups for the children and support for parents allowing families in similar circumstances to meet and share experiences.

The Family Centre brings together families living with deafness.  Come along to one of our activities and you will meet many families that are likely to be dealing with the same issues as you and can offer you support, advice or just a listening ear.

name: The Good Care Group | Live-in Care at home
description:
The Good Care Group provides award winning 24/7 Live-in Care across England, keeping clients safe and happy in the comfort of their own homes while improving their overall health and well-being. We understand the conditions our clients live with and deliver highly personalised, one-to-one care that reflects individual needs, choices, wishes, and social preferences.  

Our multidisciplinary team leads our delivery of complex care through our specialist services, we are experts in dementia care, Parkinson's, stroke, MS and palliative care along with companionship and respite services. We provide permanent care placements, and periods of short term respite care following hospital discharge, in an emergency or if your primary family carer needs to take a break or holiday.

We understand that choice, comfort and dignity are essential to happiness; this is why we carefully match our expertly trained carers to each and every client, considering their needs and personality.

Our exceptional quality of care has earned us an ‘Outstanding’ rating from the Care Quality Commission (CQC) in all five inspection measures, which gives you peace of mind when placing your trust in us.

Fees: Please contact individual practitioners via our website

name: The Home Edit Bristol - Home Organising & Decluttering
description:
We are Bristol based Professional Home Organisation business with a passion for creating innovative & unique solutions to your Home Organisation problems.

We recognise that storage solutions are not a one-size-fits-all approach as everyone has unique needs and requirements that require different systems;

We Listen , We Plan, We Source, We Deliver 

✨Do you often feel overwhelmed & embarrassed by your home? 
✨ Are you unable to feel calm & relaxed? 
✨ Do you have difficulty finding items you need?
✨ Do you feel like you don’t have enough space?
✨Are you moving home soon? 
✨ Do you lack motivation to get your home organised or don't know where to begin? 
✨Do you need help choosing the right storage solutions to best suit your home?

Following a FREE Initial Consultation to find out more we'll recommend which one of our services is best suited;

Home Organisation

Decluttering 

Space Planning & Storage Maximisation

Home Move Services: Pre-listing Edit & Luxury Home from Home Unpacking

Bereavement Clearance Management

​

We take full control of all projects from start to finish; whether it be Planning, Researching, Sourcing, Recommending, Assembling and Implementing we've got it covered so you don't have to worry; we'll just keep you updated.


supportive - affordable - non judgemental 

Check out our 5 star reviews on Facebook 

https://www.facebook.com/TheHomeEditBristol

Take a look at our recent projects on Instagram:

https://instagram.com/the_home_edit_bristol?igshid=MmIzYWVlNDQ5Yg==








Ask yourself...

name: The HOPE Project
description:
The Hope Project provides short-term emotional and practical support for men aged 30-64, specifically those who are in psychological distress or have recently self-harmed.  Our aim is to prevent suicide among this high-risk group.

To make a referral or to talk to us about signposting to other agencies and advice please email us on hope@second-step.co.uk.

Our experienced support workers work with men across Bristol, North Somerset and South Gloucestershire over a twelve-week period, and specifically focus on helping men who aren’t currently using mental health services. We know that 62% of all suicides are by people who aren’t known or connected to any services.

Client Paul says our work is life-saving:

"Through my torment, being able to speak to Hannah and make a plan for my life, has been a game-changer."

organization.name: Second Step
organization.description:
Second Step
Second Step

name: The Human Nature Project
description: Free forest therapy group sessions led by qualified and experience facilitators. Open to all, booking required. Tuesdays in Leigh Woods Green Barn. Free tea! Ideal for those who would like to enjoy time in a beautiful outdoor setting, meet new people, and strengthen mental wellbeing by strengthening their connection to the natural world. To find out more or book a place, visit our website: https://www.wearelightbox.co.uk/humannatureproject
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: If you have any access needs, you will be asked to share them with us during the booking in process. Wheelchair accessible. Toilets available onsite.

organization.name: Light Box Project CIC
organization.description: We run The Human Nature Project - forest therapy group sessions in Leigh Woods, Bristol. Free to attend, booking required.

name: The Jessie May Trust
description: The Jessie May Trust is a Bristol-based charity providing nursing care at home for children and young people with life limiting conditions who are not expected to live beyond the age of 19. We offer end of life care and bereavement support, as well as vital respite sessions and emotional support to those children’s families. This allows families to make the most of the precious time they have together and to create treasured family memories.

organization.name: The Jessie May Trust
organization.description:
Jessie May is a charity that provides hospice at home care for terminally ill children in Bristol and the surrounding area. The charity was set up by the parents of Jessica May Purrington, a little girl who died at home aged 4 months, surrounded by her family and her nurses. 
The Jessie May Trust has a team of dedicated nurses who provide care to children and families during a child’s life and after their death.

name: The Junction Project
description: We provide housing and support for people aged 18 onwards who are homeless and are experiencing a drug and alcohol problem.

organization.name: The Junction Project
organization.description:
The Junction Project
The Junction Project

name: The Limes
description:
Day support, four days a week for people under 70 years of age who have dementia. The Limes is a self contained unit with a homely atmosphere situated on the ground floor of the Old School House at the Kingswood Foundation Estate. Access to an enclosed terrace and use of the grounds. Provides a friendly, stimulating and safe environment where younger people with dementia are encouraged to retain their individuality, skills and maintain a sense of well-being.
Clients attending The Limes are generally funded by their Local Authority Adult Social Care service following an assessment of their needs. However, clients and their carers may also choose to make their own arrangements.

They offer:
* Day care facilities for up to 6 younger people with dementia.
* Carefully selected quality support workers trained to high standards to ensure the individual potential of clients is fulfilled and maintained with dignity.
* Individual home assessment of prospective clients by the care manager and periodic reviews of client support plans.
* A choice of purposeful age related activities designed to meet individual needs together with a range of outdoor pursuits.
* Snacks and drinks throughout the day and lunch, for which a nominal charge is made.

* Information and advice to carers.
* Advice to carers on transport arrangements for clients.

Clients:
* Below the age of 70 years of age.
* Will have a consultant diagnosis of dementia.
* Will benefit from individual care within a stimulating environment.

* Individual reviews of client care will be carried out in partnership with carers.

Those who are interested are welcome to visit The Limes at any time, by making an appointment or call for more information.

organization.name: Southern Brooks Community Partnership
organization.description:
We’re a community development organisation, bringing people together to build strong communities. Since 1988, we’ve been working with people of all ages to help them live happy, healthy lives.
What do we do?

We work with communities to understand local needs, and bring people together to find better ways of doing things.
We provide practical support to help people get on in their lives, from training courses to job clubs to one-to-one support.
We run a community café and youth centre, where people can connect, try new things and get support to make changes in their lives and communities.
We work with families, older people and children and young people

name: The Live-in Care Hub
description:
The Live-in Care Hub is a not-for-profit organisation aimed at helping older people and their families find the best possible form of live-in care.  We're based in Tewkesbury but our member organisations provide live-in care services across the country. 

We conduct ongoing, independent research in conjunction with the PSSRU - the world-renowned Personal Social Services Research Unit (a collaboration between the University of Kent and the London School of Economics). The research clearly indicates that older people are safer and healthier being looked after in their own homes by professional carers and so we’re passionate about getting the message out and promoting local live-in-care providers.

name: The Matthew Tree Project
description:
The Matthew Tree project believe everyone has the capability to be remarkable and has the ability to excel in something. To empower and support people who have fallen into crisis, for whatever reason, to rebuild their lives and create a better, healthier, happier future.

The vision is to create a sense of community where people feel safe, understood and supported. To connect people and families in crisis together with services, activities and skills training they need and would benefit from, in a seamless and easy way.To provide opportunities for people and communities to help each other and contribute towards making the world around them a better place to be.

The vision is also to succeed in the above so that one day we can close down The Matthew Tree Project because there is no need for it.

organization.name: The Matthew Tree Project
organization.description:
'Rebuilding Lives' is the pioneering and holistic working model created by The Matthew Tree Project (TMTP) which provides a complete 'wrap-around' range of support and guidance services for those living on the very edge of society, hit by crisis and at risk of homelessness.

The Matthew Tree Project holistic ethos is to meet people at their point of crisis. To love. To understand. To empower. To support. In the centre of our ‘tree’ logo is the word ‘love’, written in Chinese, to depict branches of compassion reaching out to people in their time of need.

The simple and compassionate act of giving people food on a weekly basis has created a safe and positive environment to build relationship and gain an understanding of each person’s circumstances. This allows us to engage on a much deeper level - to get to the heart of the problem, and then support people to move from crisis to independence in the best possible way.

name: The Mindful Parenting and Community Project
description:
The Mindful Parenting & Community Project (MPCP) was established by a group of Bristol based Mindfulness Practitioners to support you to manage your mental health and wellbeing through connecting with mindfulness as an individual, parent, child, teacher or community.  

We aim to focus our support on the more deprived areas of the South West to bring improved health and wellbeing to those that are more isolated or vulnerable within their community. 

We offer a variety of grant funded mindfulness based courses based on a particular theme as well as serving the general public at large.

What we offer:
We offer a variety of: 
1:1 sessions, 
Information workshops, 
Bespoke workshops, 
Mindfulness Courses 
Retreat Days and Weekends
​
All of which can be tailor made to the specific needs of the group and delivered in a variety of venues within Bristol and the South West.  
​
We are currently offering regular Mindfulness Support Sessions during the COVID 19 restricted period to support health and wellbeing during strange and difficult times.

name: The National Autistic Society
description: The National Autistic Society Are here to transform lives and change attitudes to help create a society that works for autistic people.

name: The Pain Toolkit
description:
The Pain Toolkit website developed from the Pain Toolkit, a simple information booklet that provides you with handy tips and skills to support you along the way to managing your pain. It is not meant to be the last word in pain self-management but a handy guide to help you get started - all you need to be is willing to read it and take on board some of the suggestions.

The Pain Toolkit offers unique and tailored set of twelve tools to help and aid in pain self-management, plus a suite of tailored resources for both healthcare professionals and people living with persistent pain. We have also curated a selection of useful links too, which we think can help.

There are online workshops, webinars, videos, podcasts and other resources of information all available to help you understand pain management. 

For more information please visit the Pain Toolkit website: https://www.paintoolkit.org

organization.name: The Pain Toolkit
organization.description: The Pain Toolkit website developed from the Pain Toolkit, a simple information booklet that provides you with handy tips and skills to support you along the way to managing your pain. It is not meant to be the last word in pain self-management but a handy guide to help you get started - all you need to be is willing to read it and take on board some of the suggestions.

name: The Park Centre Kingswood
description:
The Park Centre is a community centre located in the centre of Kingswood, where various groups gather for group activities, social support. The Centre is a single story fully accessible building, is on a bus route to/from the town centre.

The Centre is primarily run as a venue for hire for individuals, clubs, agencies, and organisations which provide activities, opportunities, and services to the community. These primarily cover education and training, social and recreational, health and fitness.

Community Groups have been formed for example the 50+ club which has over 60 members which has also led to spin off groups these include an Arts and Craft group. All these groups are run by Committee members of the park Centre. Other groups include self-help groups, Community Groups, and local business.

organization.name: The Park Centre Kingswood
organization.description: The Park Centre is a versatile venue-for-hire for the local community. We provide Room Hire, Children's Parties, Community Groups, Free Courses & a Cafe.

name: The Park Centre Knowle
description:
The Park Centre Knowle The Centre occupies a 15 acre site on the main bus route through Knowle. It opened in 2000 as a hub of community activity including learning, business, support services and leisure.

What's On?

Click on the link to find out more - What’s on – The Park Centre

Facilities: 

The Park has all sorts of affordable facilities that are available for use by our local community. We want to provide opportunities for you to enjoy socialising, leisure time, sport and healthy living, and for meeting up, whether for business or for celebrations.

Hire:

We have plenty of conference and meeting space available onsite to suit everyone. We can accommodate large numbers for performances, conferences or large get-togethers or we can provide smaller meeting rooms with audio visual technology. We are also a great venue for parties and community events. We offer refreshments and catering from our on-site café. We are easily accessible by public transport and there is also plenty of parking on site. Rooms are available to hire at reasonable prices. For more information, please use our contact form or call us on 0117 903 9770.

Who's Here:

Follow the link to see who is at The Park Centre - Who’s here – The Park Centre 

Education and Training:

We are passionate about supporting learners aged 16-18 years to gain qualifications, skills and confidence to help them towards the world of work. We do this in a nurturing environment that considers the individual needs of our young people.

Learners are all encouraged to gain additional work experience. Alongside each course you also study Functional Skills English and Mathematics or GCSE English, GCSE Maths and Employability Skills.

We are accredited to the matrix Standard, demonstrating the high quality Information, Advice and Guidance we provide to our learners.

Alternative education:

Young people aged 14-16 can be referred to us by schools, Local Authority or other organisations if their current provision is not meeting their needs.

This will be tailored to the individual and will be for half a day.  Usually Learners join in with our Post 16 provision and gain vocational qualifications. 

We are on the Alternative Education Framework.

organization.name: The Park Centre Knowle
organization.description:
A hub of community, activity, business, learning, support services and leisure in Knowle.
The Park has all sorts of facilities that are affordably available for use by our local community. We want to provide opportunities for you to enjoy socialising, leisure time, sport and healthy living, and for meeting up, whether for business or for celebrations.
There are a range of sport and leisure facilities on site – something to suit every age, interest and ability. We have a friendly, welcoming gym with a range of membership options, including ‘pay as you go’.
The Park also offers alternative education and has a cafe on site.

Available to hire.

name: The RAF Families Federation
description: The RAF Families Federation exists to make life better for Service personnel and their families, at home and overseas. We provide reliable information on the topics that matter most to you, support you through to the resolution of problems resulting from Service and make long-term positive changes happen for the Armed Forces Community.

organization.name: The RAF Families Federation
organization.description: The RAF Families Federation exists to make life better for Service personnel and their families, at home and overseas. We provide reliable information on the topics that matter most to you, support you through to the resolution of problems resulting from Service and make long-term positive changes happen for the Armed Forces Community.

name: The Royal British Legion
description:
We provide lifelong support to serving and ex-serving personnel and their families.

Our support starts after one day of service and continues through life, long after service is over.

From providing expert advice and guidance, to recovery and rehabilitation, through to transitioning to civilian life – we can be by their side every step of the way. And it’s not just members of the Armed Forces but their families too.

If there is ever a reason we can't help, our vast network will mean that we know someone who can.

organization.name: The Royal British Legion
organization.description:
he Royal British Legion is at the heart of a national network that supports our Armed Forces community.
We're here through thick and thin – ensuring their unique contribution is never forgotten. We've been here since 1921 and we'll be here as long as they need us. 

We are the country’s largest Armed Forces charity, with 180,000 members, 110,000 volunteers and a network of partners and charities; helping us give support wherever and whenever it’s needed.

name: The Sequal Trust
description: The Sequal Trust Provides communication aids to disabled people of all ages, with speech and/or movement or severe learning difficulties. Equipment issued on a life long basis with Sequal covering costs of all repairs that are not user caused. This service is available for British Citizens resident in the UK who fit their criteria. Please phone to find out criteria and procedure for obtaining help.

name: The Southmead Project
description:
The Southmead Project was founded in 1994 by Mike Peirce, MBE. He himself is a survivor of abuse and addiction, and has fought tirelessly to raise awareness of how people that have survived abuse may develop an addiction to drugs or alcohol as a way of coping with their trauma. 

​Our work supports people that have experienced abuse, as well as providing specific support for people with an addiction to drugs or alcohol.  

​We are based in Southmead in North Bristol and can support people from all over Bristol and its neighbouring areas.

organization.name: The Southmead Project
organization.description:
The Southmead Project was founded in 1994 by Mike Peirce, MBE. He himself is a survivor of abuse and addiction, and has fought tirelessly to raise awareness of how people that have survived abuse may develop an addiction to drugs or alcohol as a way of coping with their trauma. 

​Our work supports people that have experienced abuse, as well as providing specific support for people with an addiction to drugs or alcohol.  

​We are based in Southmead in North Bristol and can support people from all over Bristol and its neighbouring areas.

​

name: The Southville Centre
description:
The Southville Centre is a community hub run by BS3 Community providing accessible services and activities for people in the BS3 area.

It is a beautiful grade II listed Victorian building with an on site cafe and music and alcohol licenses. It also has four rooms available to hire for classes, meetings and events and works in partnership with Kate's Kitchen to host weddings.

Fees: Cost information room hire costs are available from our website. Costs for individual classes vary and fees are paid directly to the class organiser.

Telephone or check the website for more details.

organization.name: BS3 Community
organization.description:
BS3 Community Development was founded in 1991 to improve the lives of people living in BS3 and the surrounding area. We run two community venues; the Southville Centre and the Chessel Centre.

BS3 Community Development is a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee and as a social business we reinvest surplus generated from our profitable services into educational, arts, environmental, health and wellbeing projects that we either run directly or support partners to deliver.

name: The Triangle Lunch Club Stockwood
description:
COVID-19: PLEASE NOTE THIS ACTIVITY IS CURRENTLY SUSPENDED DUE TO COVID-19


The Triangle Lunch Club Stockwood You will be provided with a two course lunch as well as tea, coffee and a soft drink There is also a Prize Draw (£1) and you are invited to take part in a Bingo Session after the meal. It is a very social occasion when you meet existing and make new friends.     Fees: The cost is only £5 and within Stockwood, transport can be arranged for an additional £1-50.

organization.name: Age UK Triangle Lunch Club Stockwood

Age UK Triangle Lunch Club Stockwood

name: The Venchtable Gardening Group
description:
Gardening group run by the Vench Adventure Playground. 

A beginner growing group for adults. 12-2pm every Thursday (term time only). No previous growing experience required.

organization.name: The Vench
organization.description: We are The Vench, a much-loved adventure playground and community centre in Lockleaze, Bristol.

name: The Wheel 2 Learn
description:
A young people’s educational support project.

The Wheel 2 Learn is project supported by Accessible Transport 4 U (AT4U) and run by registered charity East Bristol Advice & Information Centres. 

A supportive transport service specifically for individuals who are 15 – 25 years of age, are disabled and want to access learning or further education or outdoor sport and recreational activities to help broaden their horizons and practical experiences.

Our aim is to help improve their quality of life and help them to become independent and able to consider employment or voluntary work as well as gain a better understanding of life and social integration.

We aim to be supportive and contribute to the lives of disabled young people, including those with learning difficulties, physical disabilities or mental health issues regardless of culture or social background to enable them to access learning, education and training.

organization.name: Accessible Transport 4 U
organization.description:
Accessible Transport 4 U
Door to door accessible transport for people who prefer to have their own supportive and safe transport. Helping you to get a life and become more active for what you need or want to do, day to day. The service is 365 days a year 24:7. Including Christmas and Bank holidays. We are here 4 U.

A not for profit and community interest company that aims to help you use stress free, door to destination and return if necessary 24:7 from South West of England to anywhere in the UK mainland.

name: The Willow Tree Centre
description:
The Willow Tree Centre offers a confidential free listening and support service for those facing unplanned pregnancy or following miscarriage, stillbirth, ectopic pregnancy or abortion.

The service covers Bristol, South Gloucestershire, Bath and beyond.

organization.name: The Willow Tree Centre
organization.description:
The Willow Tree Centre
The Willow Tree Centre

name: Therapeutic Chair Yoga
description:
My Therapeutic Chair yoga for Adults is most beneficial for people with restricted body movements due to disability, injury, againg, Multiply Sclerosis, Arthritis, chronic fatigue syndrome, depression, chronic pain.

We practise gently body stretching, meditation, relaxation and breathing techniques.

organization.name: Heart Within Yoga - Therapeutic Yoga for SEN

name: Therapeutic Yoga for children and teenagers SEN
description:
In my Therapeutic Yoga sessions, I use sensory and visual aids and tools, modelling poses, social stories and games. I make adaptations and modifications based on age and cognitive, social and emotional abilities.

I also teach Makaton signs yoga for nonverbal students. 

Therapeutic Yoga helps choldren and teenagers with self regulation, anxiety, ADHD, Autism, Dyslexia, Challenging behaviour, Restricted Mobility , Language Processing Difficulties and many more...

Our sessions are family friendly where parents/carers can join for free.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: Our Therapeutic yoga is inclusive and accessible to wheelchair users too

organization.name: Heart Within Yoga - Therapeutic Yoga for SEN

name: Thornbury and District League of Friends
description:
Supporting Community Health and Wellbeing

The League of Friends changed its name and constitution after receiving a large legacy and, rather than supporting Thornbury Hospital (which no longer exists), we are now reaching out to the community to offer support to any local groups which have health-related/wellbeing needs which can't otherwise be fulfilled.
We will also continue to support the Henderson Rehabilitation Unit at Grace Care Centre on Midland Way.

Thornbury and District League of Friends mission is to assist the people of Thornbury and surrounding parishes by providing such additional help and support as is approved by the Trustees for their healthcare and wellbeing, either directly or indirectly through agencies or other charities.

Also, to support the work of the rehabilitation unit in Thornbury currently known as the Henderson rehabilitation unit by providing extra care and comfort for the patients, visitors and staff of the unit.

name: Thornbury Leisure Centre
description:
Our Gym in Thornbury features its own dedicated Functional Fitness area, and separate, fully mirrored, Weight Training Area. We have the very latest in strength and conditioning equipment, including the latest innovations from Technogym with new running, climbing, cycling and rowing machines.

We also offer an extensive range of fitness classes, from the more traditional aerobics and body conditioning classes to virtual online sessions as well as offering yoga, aquafit and group cycling.

FACILITIES

  • Fully kitted out Gym
  • 2 Fitness Studios
  • 25m Main Swimming Pool with integrated Small Pool (includes pool hoist)
  • 5 Badminton Court Main Hall
  • 5-Badminton Court Severnside Sports Hall
  • 5-Rink Indoor Bowls Hall (Closed for the summer season)
  • 4 Squash Courts
  • Meeting Rooms
  • Snooker Room
  • The Thornbury Clinic Active
  • A range of Accessibility Equipment and Changing Facilities
  • ​​​​​​​PRICE LIST

ACCESSIBILITY FOR OUR DISABLED CUSTOMERS

We have a range of equipment to help customers change comfortably, and get in and out of pools safely. Our gyms have specific equipment installed to aid customers with a disability.

Thornbury offers the following facilities:

  • Dedicated parking spaces for disabled badge holders
  • Where height adjustable changing stretchers are provided full room hoist coverage is given with overhead tracking systems for use with customer’s own slings.
  • Mobile hoist
  • Separate disabled male and female changing
  • Height-adjustable changing table
  • Pool hoist

If you have a specific requirement and need further assistance please contact us on 03003330300 and we will try our best to help you.

Thornbury Active Lifestyle Centre,
Alveston Hill,
Thornbury,
BS35 3JB

organization.name: Circadian Trust/Active Lifestyles
organization.description:
We are Circadian Trust; an innovative, social enterprise operating as an independent charity, which successfully manages leisure facilities across South Gloucestershire.
We run and operate our 5 Active Lifestyle Centres, to bring our mission ‘Inspiring Active Lifestyles’ to life.

name: Thrive – using gardening to change lives
description:
At Thrive, we are passionate about the health benefits that gardening, horticulture and spending time in nature can bring.

We are a leading UK charity with over 40 years’ experience of an approach called social and therapeutic horticulture (STH). We want to help people with varying needs to access therapeutic gardening programmes and use gardening as part of personal health and wellbeing management.

We do this by:

  • Supporting our client gardeners through programmes at our 3 regional centres in Reading, Birmingham and London
  • Delivering training courses so people can go on to practice Social and Therapeutic Horticulture and other forms of Green Care
  • Sharing our knowledge freely to reach as many people as possible through the ‘Get Gardening’ section of our website, our Gardening Club newsletters and our various publications  ​​​​​​​

You can also contact us to find out about Social and Therapeutic Horticultural Projects (STH) near you.

organization.name: Thrive - using gardening to change lives

name: Time For You Service ( Sitting Services)
description:
Please note: We are unable to offer volunteer sitters at the moment, but many of our volunteers are still in touch, with carers and the person they care for, through regular phone calls. We are not currently able to take new referrals to the service. We are currently exploring how to offer carers a ‘break’ remotely and will provide further information in the coming weeks.

We provide a short break service for carers in South Gloucestershire only (not currently in Bristol).

This is a free service for carers living in South Gloucestershire, which is provided by volunteers, all of whom are supported and managed by Carers Support Centre. This service enables carers to take a 2/3 hours break on a regular basis – usually weekly or fortnightly. Our volunteers go through a robust recruitment and selection process, and receive comprehensive induction and ongoing training. Our service coordinator carefully matches volunteers with the carer and cared for person. Many volunteers have been carers themselves.

organization.name: Carers Support Centre – Bristol and South Glos
organization.description:
Our mission is to promote the rights and improve the quality of life of children and adult family carers in Bristol and South Gloucestershire.

Our vision is to make sure carers are identified, recognised, valued, respected and supported in their caring role.

Carers Support Centre is an independent registered charity, established in 1997. We have more than 12,000 local carers registered with us and deliver our services with 40 (full time equivalent) members of staff and over 170 volunteers.

Our range of services includes a confidential telephone information and advice line, carers’ magazine, Carers Emergency Card, one-to-one casework support, carers’ groups, activities for carers to take time out, regular breaks and training courses. We also work to identify and support carers in hospital and GP settings through our health team and support carers to get into – and stay in – employment.

name: Time to Talk
description: Every Monday night we hold a drop in peer support group. If you need advice, are a good listener or just want a cup of tea and a chat feel free to drop in. We all need someone to listen so if you are experiencing depression or anxiety drop in and see us and give someone a chance to help.

organization.name: JTE Hub@Shire
organization.description:
We are a brand new volunteer led initiative Jobs, Training and Enterprise Hub based in Shirehampton

We cover: Avonmouth, Sea Mills, Avonmouth and of course Shirehampton.

We know that there are many barriers to employment and aim to break these down.
The Covid epidemic has thrown in a curve ball into the mix for a lot of people.

We aim to provide courses locally that will inspire, motivate and encourage people to gain new skills improve confidence and enhance wellbeing.

We kick of the New Year with a Digital skills course starting on the 27th January.

name: Torch fellowship groups- Bristol
description: Torch fellowship groups offer Christian based fellowship where blind and sighted people meet on equal terms. Some 110 Torch Fellowship Groups meet informally on a monthly basis across the UK, with many more overseas. Locally Bristol Central Fellowship Group Meets: 1st Saturday of the month at 3.00pm Location: Summerhill Methodist Church Air Balloon Road St George Bristol BS5 8LB Contact: Rachel Lee Tel: 01495 447758 email: rrhlee@sky.com North-West Fellowship Group Meets: 2nd Saturday of the month at 3.00pm Location: Westbury-on-Trym Baptist Church Reedley Road Westbury-on-Trym Bristol BS9 3TD Contact: David Murray Tel: 0117 962 2066 email: davecmurray@aol.com South Fellowship Group Meets: Last Saturday of the month at 3.00pm Location: Counterslip Baptist Church Hall 648 Wells Road Whitchurch Bristol BS14 9HT Contact: Stewart Simmons Tel: 0117 9624220 e-mail s@stewartsimmons.plus.com Young People Meets: 3rd Saturday in February, June and October Location: Venues variable Contact: Liz Gould Tel: 0117 9423615 email: melgould21@gmail.com   All Torch Trust services have a Christian basis, but are open to people of all faiths or none. http://www.torchtrust.org/smartweb/Groups%20and%20Fellowship/torch-fellowship-groups https://www.wellaware.org.uk/projects/torch-trust-befriending/

name: Transport Support Services for Disabled People
description:
These Gov.uk web pages contain lots of helpful information on using public transport, vehicle tax exemptions, car adaptations, the Motability Scheme, the Blue Badge Scheme, how to check station accessibility and much more. You will also be able to find out about your transport rights as a disabled person:

https://www.gov.uk/transport-disabled

organization.description: Gov.uk is the United Kingdom's public sector information website, created by the Government Digital Service to provide a single point of access to HM Government services.

name: Travel West

Trinity’s vision is for everyone to have the opportunity to access and shape arts and culture because we believe art improves individual well-being, empowers communities and enhances society.

name: Types of Care - St Monica Trust
description:
Care and compassion are at the heart of everything we do. It’s been that way for nearly 100 years and is the reason why we’re well-known and respected for the quality of our care in Bristol and North Somerset.

Our welcoming care homes are set within the beautiful surroundings of our retirement villages. There are village care teams for those who live independently in our accommodation too. We also bring care and support to people who live at home within the Bristol area. Whatever your needs, we’re here for you.

We are still accepting admissions where possible. Please call our admissions team for more information. 0117 919 4263

Dementia care

Our specially designed dementia care homes and services are inspired by the contribution that people living with all types of dementia continue to make. Our approach is based on the quality of the relationships that we build and the way that the environment is designed to support interactions, which give meaning and purpose to every day. 

FIND OUT MORE

Nursing care

The St Monica Trust’s nursing care homes provide care and companionship for residents in beautifully designed environments. Our aim is to make sure you get the best out of every day and enjoy a friendly atmosphere where you can feel truly at home.

FIND OUT MORE


Respite care

We offer short-term care with comfortable en-suite rooms, well-equipped for all your needs, and access to support from our experienced therapy team. Rooms can be booked in advance like in a hotel, so you get to choose when you’d like to check in and check out.

FIND OUT MORE


Residential care

The new residential care wing at Charterhouse in Keynsham offers the assistance and security that comes from living in a care home to those who don’t need nursing care. Our friendly team are primed to provide personal and practical support to make it easy for you to continue enjoying your life the way you want.

FIND OUT MORE


End of life care

We’re nationally recognised for our award-winning palliative and end of life care, which sensitively encompasses all aspects of your physical, spiritual and emotional well-being. Working with you and your loved ones, we’re here to provide relief and support for as long as you need us.

FIND OUT MORE​​​​​​​

Care at Home

Whether you need extra help around the home, companionship or specialised care, we offer a flexible home care service that is tailored specifically for you. Our friendly expert carers provide care and support in your own home and you can choose the hours that work for you. We also offer a fast track service so you can be assessed and have your very own plan of care created within 24 hours.

FIND OUT MORE


Dementia day service

Our dementia day care service is inspired by the contribution that people living with Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia continue to make. Our positive approach is based on the quality of the relationships that we build and the way that the environment is designed to support interactions, which give meaning and purpose to every day.  

FIND OUT MORE


Village care

As time moves on, you can enjoy some extra help from someone you trust. Whether it's help preparing a meal, companionship or you have more complex requirements, our friendly village care teams are ready to lend a hand. This specialist service is available for residents living in our retirement villages.

FIND OUT MORE


Pastoral care

The spiritual and religious needs of our residents are important to us, regardless of faith or religious affiliation. Our pastoral care team enrich our communities by ensuring that they are places where people feel they belong and can make a positive contribution. The pastoral care team are ready to provide comfort and support when times are challenging as well as celebrate life through festivals and special occasions.

FIND OUT MORE

The Best Experience of Ageing

The St Monica Trust has long been recognised for the high quality accommodation, care and support it provides for older and disabled people. Regarded as one of the leading providers of continuing care in the south west of England, the Trust supports a wide variety of people with differing needs in many imaginative ways and in a number of settings.

name: Unique
description: Unique Unique is a source of information and support to families and individuals affected by any rare chromosome disorder and to the professionals who work with them. Established in 1984, Unique is a UK-based charity but welcomes members worldwide. Membership of Unique is free but the group receives no government funding and is heavily reliant on donations and fundraising to continue its work. Unique, offers contact with families with an affected member who has the same rare chromosome disorder, or who has similar symptoms or practical concerns, irrespective of specific chromosome disorder. It produces a comprehensive range of family-friendly, medically-verified information guides on a variety of rare chromosome disorders. A network of local contacts promotes awareness of rare chromosome disorders to the general public and professionals. Unique co-ordinates families to assist in research and has password-protected discussion forums for registered members, it also has social networking sites on FaceBook, Twitter, etc. It publishes a magazine three times a year. Unique hosts occasional study and family conference weekends. Unique has over 8,000 affected families and many relevant professionals as members worldwide in 81 countries.

organization.name: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust
organization.description:
University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust (UHBW) was formed on 1 April 2020 following the merger of University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust and Weston Area Health NHS Trust.
Bringing together a combined workforce of over 13,000 staff, the new Trust delivers over 100 different clinical services across 10 different sites serving a core population of more than 500,000 people.
With services from the neonatal intensive care unit to care of the elderly, we provide care to the people of Bristol, Weston and the south west from the very beginning of life to its later stages.

name: University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust Services
description:
BRI Hospital - The Bristol Royal Infirmary (BRI) is a teaching hospital with close links to Bristol University and provides acute medicine and surgery, critical care, trauma, orthopaedic and accident and emergency services to the population of Bristol. 

South Bristol Community Hospital - 

University Hospitals Bristol is providing a number of services at South Bristol, listed below:

  • Inpatient & Outpatient rehabilitation
  • Day hospital services - including a Rapid Assessment Clinic for Older people - RACOP
  • Urgent care centre ( managed by Bristol Community Health)
  • Outpatients - covering a broad range of services
  • Day surgery
  • Diagnostics
  • Community dental treatment & dental teaching
  • Neuro-physiotherapy outpatients

Cancer Support and Information Centre - 

Open:  Monday - Thursday, 8.30am - 4.30pm

                                 Friday, 8.30am - 4pm

Contact number: 0117 3423369

Email: cancerinformationandsupport@uhbw.nhs.uk

Primary Care Dental Clinic - provides dental care for people who are unable to access treatment from a general dental practitioner (GDP) because of special needs, or disabilities. This includes, for example, those individuals with mobility problems, learning difficulties or complex medical histories, and those who are housebound. 

Dental Hospital - The University of Bristol Dental Hospital is a Centre of Excellence providing routine and specialist clinical dental services for the South West. 

Pain Clinic - The Central Health Clinic currently provides the following services: A Pain Clinic for people experiencing persistent (chronic) pain. 

Pain Clinic office (for other appointments / queries),  tel: 0117 342 7575

Pain Clinic, Central Health Clinic, UHBristol NHS Trust, Tower Hill, Bristol, BS2 0JD

Travelling to and from UHB Hospitals including shuttle buses

We offer a full NHS General Practice service for all University of Bristol students and their dependents who reside within the practice area. It also includes some, but not all, addresses in Bishopston, Horfield, Henleaze, Stoke Bishop, Westbury-on-Trym, Leigh Woods, Sea Mills and St. Paul's. name: Vassall's Cafe
description:
Cafes

We run two cafes in the Bristol/South Gloucestershire area; Barn Café at Grimsbury Farm in Kingswood, and the Vassall Centre Café in Fishponds.

The cafes provide opportunities for vocational training and paid employment. The aim is to help people transition into the workplace, and gain transferable life and social skills. They make and sell delicious freshly prepared food and tasty cakes.

Vassall's Café is a new enterprise managed by Brandon Trust, a charity supporting people with learning disabilities established in Bristol in 1994. Our aim is to provide people with learning disabilities with the opportunity to gain vocational training and paid employment. We also aim to provide our customers with great food made with high quality ingredients, served with a smile."

organization.name: Brandon Trust
organization.description:
The Brandon Trust provides individualised, high-quality support that is genuinely life-enhancing. This ranges from light-touch enabling services through to long-term residential care for people with complex needs. Headquartered in Bristol, we operate across the south of England and south Midlands, from London through Warwickshire to Cornwall. Our support is designed and delivered by a staff team of over 2,000 and underpinned by our values. 

We are committed to working with the people we support, and those who surround them, to shape a future where every person with a learning disability will be empowered to live their life to its full potential.

name: Victim Support
description:
Need help after crime?

Get in touch anytime for independent, free, and confidential advice:

  • Call Supportline on 08 08 16 89 111
  • Text Relay: use the Relay UK app or contact us in BSL
  • Start a live chat
  • Fill out our online form below (a member of your local area team will contact you within three working days).

In an emergency you should always call 999.

Our services are confidential. We will only share information about you without your consent if we’re concerned about your, or someone else’s safety, or if we’re required to by law.

name: Volunteer To Help Prevent Sexual Harm
description:
Volunteer To Help Prevent Sexual Harm

As a volunteer in a Circle of Support and Accountability, you’ll make an important contribution to your community by helping reduce the risk of further sexual harm by a known perpetrator. A Circle is a small group of carefully trained and selected volunteers who meet regularly with an individual who has sexually harmed. Volunteers hold the individual to account for their behaviour and support their safe reintegration into the community. They work closely with the responsible statutory organisations. Exciting volunteering opportunities in Bristol for people who can commit a few hours per week for a minimum of 12 months include our Young People’s Service; Prison Project and Community Circles for Adults with Intellectual Disabilities. We provide training, support and reimburse expenses. Appointment requires satisfactory DBS Check and references. We are particularly interested in recruiting men who are currently under-represented.

name: Volunteering - Milestones Trust
description:
Volunteering - Milestones Trust offer lots of different opportunities to support our service users, including sharing your hobbies or interests, befriending one of our service users, helping people take part in activities or accompanying individuals on trips. No specific skills are needed, just a willingness to bring an added dimension to someone's life. The hours our volunteers give enrich the lives and wellbeing of the people we support through conversation, laughter, shared experiences and encouraging their independence. Taking the time to build a rapport with someone reaps many rewards for them and for you.

You won’t just be supporting someone with a learning disability, mental health need or dementia. The interests of the people we support are as diverse as they are, so you’ll be supporting them to meet their goals, engage in meaningful activities, and fulfil their potential.

You could be accompanying the person you support on fun days out such as trips to the cinema or theatre, walks in the park or to cheer on their favourite sports team. As a volunteer, you could be supporting someone in their homes, to get involved in activities like baking, gardening, arts and crafts or improving their computer skills. The person you support may want you to help them attend a regular exercise class or social club, go swimming or visit the local amenities. More information and how to get involved: http://www.milestonestrust.org.uk/get-involved/volunteer-with-us/

name: Volunteering at Tortworth Forest Centre
description:
FREE MINIBUS SERVICE PROVIDED FROM BRISTOL to help you access this opportunity in a beautiful woodland.

Our Woodland Management Days provide a safe, supportive and friendly environment for people to take part in arboretum restoration work, spend a day outside, meet others, learn, and develop new skills.

We work with people who are in recovery or experiencing other mental health struggles.  Volunteers should be physically able to spend a day outside doing practical tasks. We don’t crack the whip! We take breaks and help people work at a comfortable pace.  

There are usually three staff members on site including one female staff member. All are first aid trained. We provide all tools, gloves and guidance.

Tasks include scything, cutting back bramble, collecting firewood, splitting logs, making a dead hedge, cutting up a fallen branch, cutting saplings, clearing paths etc. The days are crucial to the restoration and management of the arboretum.  We also incorporate opportunities for volunteers and staff alike to learn about the trees, plants and the wildlife in the woods. 

Our facilities are basic but we do have shelter and we have a compost loo on site. Unfortunately the days are not suitable for people in wheelchairs or with limited mobility.

name: Walking Well - South Gloucestershire
description:
Walking Well (Previously known as Walking for Health)

You may be aware that Walking for Health (nationally) will end later this year to be replaced by Ramblers Wellbeing Walks. At South Gloucestershire Council we have decided to run our health walks scheme independently of them.

The new scheme will be called Walking Well and will focus on helping people who are inactive become more active.

All walks are free and led by a group of trained leaders who can help you take the first steps to a more active lifestyle, as well as being a great way to meet new people.

The walks are between 30 and 90 minutes, designed to suit different walking abilities. These walks are designed to accommodate any walker’s needs, allowing people to walk the distance they feel comfortable with.

People of all ages and walking abilities are supported, including those who use wheelchairs or have other access requirements. To find out more or ask any questions, please contact us: Telephone: 01454 863440 or Email: walking@southglos.gov.uk

All walkers walk at their own risk. During the briefing at the start of each walk potential hazards are highlighted. We would be very grateful if walkers could pay particular attention to the briefing for their own safety and the safety of others. Please don’t walk if you are feeling unwell.

No specialist equipment is needed for our walks but please dress appropriately for the weather.

Contact us

Telephone: 01454 863440

Email: walking@southglos.gov.uk

name: We Care Home Improvements
description:
Bristol Showroom

Come and see for yourself what an adapted bathroom, kitchen or living room really looks like

Have you had a fall recently? Do you have health concerns? Or perhaps you are looking ahead and want to make changes now so you can stay independent in your own home later. Whatever the reason, come visit us at out Home Independence Centre where you can view our adapted room displays, try out our stylish and innovative products and discover what works best for you.

Adapting your home to suit you: adapted bathrooms, stair lifts, recliner chairs and more

Our Home Independence Centre has a range of adapted room displays including bathrooms, wet rooms, kitchens, living areas and bedrooms. You’ll find products designed to make your home life easier, like shower seats, grab rails, easy-open showers, non-slip flooring, stair lifts and all kinds of gadgets. Our specialists can also talk to you about fittings which help people living with dementia.

Stylish range of contemporary products

At our showroom, friendly, knowledgeable staff will be on hand to understand your needs and show you around. We have a huge range of contemporary fixtures and fittings to choose from. Let us show you how an adapted bathroom can be stylish too.

name: WECIL - The West Of England Centre For Inclusive Living
description:
WECIL - The West Of England Centre For Inclusive Living

WECIL are a forward thinking user led charity dedicated to disabled people, we work together to enable choice to challenge the barriers to independent living through the delivery of high quality support and advice. We believe that this first-hand experience provides us with unrivalled experience in our field, enabling us to offer sound advice and support to our community.

We listen and understand the needs of our community so that we can continue to support them with whatever they need.

We provide: Direct Payment Support Benefits Advice, Disabled people's Helpline, Specialist Employment Advice Services for Young Disabled People, Peer Support Training for other organisations and employers - Including: Disability Equality Training Access Audits Consultancy.

We always welcome new members to our community, so please do get in contact with us if you would like more information about the services and support that we offer.

We are proud to be a Disability Confident Employer and leader, and we are currently helping other organisations gain this status. If you would like to join this positive move forward then please contact us on 0117 9479918. WECIL also runs a helpline for disabled people in Bristol to get in touch with any disability-related question.

Our advisors can answer your queries on a range of topics, such as Where can I get a blue badge? How can I apply for a disability-related welfare benefit? My child has additional needs – are there any services she can access? If there is a question we cannot answer we will signpost you to somewhere that can, or give you as much information as possible.

Get in touch - The helpline is open from Monday to Friday 9am – 5pm Call 0117 947 9922

Email disabledpeopleshelpline@wecil.co.uk (Please note – the helpline service is for Bristol residents only)

organization.name: WECIL (West of England Centre for Inclusive Living)

Helping you to achieve better health and wellbeing, no matter where you are starting from. It’s easier to make changes with someone cheering you on!

We offer a range of services and activities for all ages, and all levels of health and fitness – basically there is something for everyone! The outdoor areas include play facilities, picnic areas, art installations, an Amphitheatre, outdoor gym equipment, a measured mile for walking or running, and football and basketball nets.

Our main goal is to provide high quality services to prevent illness, promote good health and assist recovery after medical treatment. We are happy to answer any questions you may have and look forward to meeting you soon.

TALK CLUB IS A TALKING AND LISTENING CLUB FOR MEN.  

Talk Club is a Male Mental Fitness Movement. 

It’s a talking and listening club for men.  

It’s a support network for ways to keep mentally fit. 

It’s a community of men looking after each other.

It’s here to remind all men that they are not alone, that other men feel exactly the same way they do, and if we share our feelings we can become mentally strong. 

Together we can change the way we look after our mental health and end

name: Welbeing Resources and Community Events
description:
Community Organisation providing Resources and Events for Health, Happiness and Life Long Learning!

Movement Foundations is all about bringing awareness to and inspiring activitives for Self Care. Our principles nurture responsibility for ourselves and the planet as well as being fun and feeling good!

The FREE WELLBEING RESOURCES available here are created in collaboration with expert Contributors in the fields of Movement, Nature, Holistic Health, Embodiment and Empowerment. The school program aims to support parents, teachers and the wider community by providing easy-to-understand resources for the positive development of physical and emotional health.

We organise Experience Days and occasional workshops (often suitable for the whole family) which provide opportunities to join together in community and supports life long learning. Join our community and include more self care, environmental care, natural movement and nature play into your life.

name: Well Aware
description: Our Well Aware website provides information on a wide range of organisations; support groups, community groups, events and activities that can help improve your health and wellbeing in Bristol and South Gloucestershire. Find out what’s happening near you with our map search and links to travel information. If you don’t have access to the internet just give us a call 0808 808 5252. One of our friendly advisers will search the database and send you the information you need, either by email or post. This is a free phone number, including from mobiles. Our telephone service is available Monday – Thursday, 9am-5pm and 9am-4:30pm on Fridays. Alternatively, email us at infoservices@thecareforum.org.uk

Well Aware

name: Wellbeing Economy Consultancy
description: Our consultancy brings together multi disciplinary teams to embed a new way of thinking and doing across departments, sectors, teams and social divides. We help co-produce rigorous and accessible research and resources to help decision makers and communities understand their role in building an economy and society fit for the challenges of the 21st century.  Innovative frameworks, measurement tools and data help to create a golden thread between citizen and society.

organization.name: Centre for Thriving Places
organization.description: Centre for Thriving Places

name: Wellbeing in Nature Online sessions - from WildPace
description:
WildPace offer these online wellbeing in nature sessions to enjoy the benefits that nature connection brings us. Nature connection relaxes and restores us, boosting wellbeing and improving our resilience, mood and feelings.

Each week we look at what we love about nature, share what inspires us and take a short guided video walk, connecting to the season, wildlife and natural events.

During these sessions we engage with the 5 pathways to nature connectedness – contact with the senses, noticing the emotions nature brings, noticing nature’s beauty, the meaning nature brings us and our compassion for nature.

There’s an invitation to some nature-based mindfulness, just spending a little time being present in our senses. This which is shown to have a strong and lasting beneficial effect in activating our connectedness.

Other activites may include a “bring and share” based on natural objects, nature-based creativies or crafts and book and film recommendations.

Who?

The sessions are primarily for people who have less access to nature perhaps for social, economic, physical or other reasons, coupled with a desire to improve wellbeing.

Values and character of sessions

The sessions are a place to have a break from everyday life and to relax and enjoy a sense of community based on our shared experiences and joy of nature and are a kind and caring space.

When and where?

These 1 ½ hour sessions are on a Thursday morning 10am to 11.30am

I will send instructions well in advance when you book your session so you know how to join.

Fees and booking

Fees are on a pay as you can basis on a sliding scale starting from £6.00 per session. Book a session by selecting dates below. Numbers are usually restricted to 10 per session. You can book as many sessions as you wish to, there is no upper or lower limit. Just book and turn up and enjoy what nature has to offer.

Book Here https://wildpace.co.uk/whats-on/nature-and-wellbeing-online/

name: Wellbeing Services
description:
Last April 2019, we began a wellbeing service for LGBTQ+ people in South Gloucestershire.

It’s part of the One You South Gloucestershire wellbeing service led by Southern Brooks Community Partnerships and South Gloucestershire Council.

We offer monthly LGBTQ+ wellbeing sessions for exploring our wellbeing needs while supporting people to try local services, such as;

  • peer support groups;
  • wellbeing courses;
  • social prescribing and so on.

During our Covid-19 pandemic lock down, we’re unable to run our wellbeing sessions in person, so we used the video conferencing website, Zoom, instead.

Our Wellbeing sessions cover the Five Ways to Wellbeing, which are:

  • connecting
  • learning
  • taking notice
  • being active
  • volunteering

As LGBTQ+ people, we’ll explore the barriers and solutions to these, so we feel more connected in our communities.

How will I benefit?

It allows LGBTQ+ people a safe space to talk openly about our issues. And talk with other people who also identify as LGBTQ+. Therefore, a deeper level of conversation, sharing, signposting and support can happen.

Sign-up

Our monthly LGBTQ+ wellbeing sessions are online until further notice.

Please email us, so we can send you our Zoom web links:

Email: wellbeing@diversitytrust.org.uk

Next online Wellbeing Session: Sunday 31 May from 4-6pm

name: Wellspring Settlement
description:
On 1 February 2020 Barton Hill Settlement and Wellspring Healthy Living Centre merged to become Wellspring Settlement. Our vision is to  bring together all the strengths and skills of the two organisations to provide more for our local communities.

Wellspring Settlement enables our community to actively participate in positive, life-affirming activities. We offer a unique space for residents of Barton Hill and the wider area to celebrate, learn, create, develop, relax, socialise and play. From young people to the more mature; from new residents of our locality to those who have lived here all of their lives are all welcome. 

We're also home to many tenant organisations,

  • Dhek Bhal
  • Bristol Somali Resource Centre
  • Changes Bristol
  • Barton Hill Boxing Club (link is to Facebook page)
  • Travelling Light Theatre Company
  • Bristol Multi-Faith Forum
  • Child and Family Consultation Services (NHS CAMHS)
  • West of England Works

We also hire facilities. Details are here.​​​​​​​

The Settlement is the cornerstone of our community in Barton Hill. Each year, more than 45 community groups and local residents come here to meet and make connections, find support systems and to take advantage of our many resources. Want to know what we have for you? View today’s events above or visit our complete calendar to learn more about upcoming events, training courses and regular activities. See you soon!

Support you can access at Wellspring Settlement

description:
The West of England Rural Network is a charity working with rural communities in South Gloucestershire, Bath & North East Somerset, North Somerset & Bristol. We support and work with communities, businesses, social enterprises, organisations and individuals on a wide range of topics that impact on rural areas.

Through the West of England Rural network, Village Agents support vulnerable people in rural areas by linking them with advice and support to help them live independently.
